title: Which are the 5 best movies one must watch? - Quora

response.answer_text: Since your question isn’t specific, I can’t possibly give you a specific answer. You do realize that there are TONS of movies out there, right?! I’m a big cineaste and have watched a huuuuge load of movies but there are still many movies I plan to watch but haven’t yet! And believe me that I could give anyone, independent of personal taste, many recommendations! With that being said, there are some movies with exceptional quality that completely blew people’s minds. Critics occasionally call them masterpieces and some even are deemed milestones of movie industry. I’ve noted all the movies I’ve watched and considered a movie of exceptional quality. Let me share this list with you and all the other quora-users and if you watched and liked some of them, please tell other people about your experience so that the lesser known of these gems get the attention they deserve: Nosferatu (1922) The Gold Rush (1925) The General (1926) Metropolis (1927) Der blaue Engel (1930) M/M – Eine Stadt sucht einen Mörder (1931) Frankenstein (1931) King Kong (1933) Modern Times (1936) Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs (1937) Bringing Up Baby (1938) Gone with the Wind (1939) Pinocchio (1940) Fantasia (1940) The Great Dictator (1940) Citizen Kane (1941) Bambi (1942) Casablanca (1942) The Third Man (1949) Rashomon (1950) A Streetcar Named Desire (1951) Singin’ in the Rain (1952) High Noon (1952) Le Salaire de la peur (1953) La Strada (1954) Rear Window (1954) Shichinin no Samurai (1954) To Catch a Thief (1955) 12 Angry Men (1957) The Bridge on the River Kwai (1957) Vertigo (1958) Some Like it Hot (1959) The Apartment (1960) Psycho (1960) The Time Machine (1960) Lolita (1962) The Birds (1963) Mary Poppins (1964) Dr. Strangelove or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb (1964) Ship of Fools (1965) Il buono, il brutto, il cattivo (1966) The Graduate (1967) 2001: A Space Odyssey (1968) C’era una volta il West (1968) Twisted Nerve (1968) Clockwork Orange (1971) The Godfather I- III (1972-90) The Exorcist (1973) Jaws (1975) One Flew Over The Cuckoo’s Nest (1975) Taxi Driver (1976) Star Wars IV- VI (1977-83) Apocalypse Now (1979) Alien (1979) Die Blechtrommel (1979) The Elephant Man (1980) The Shining (1980) Tenshi no Tamago (1985) Blue Velvet (1986) The Fly (1986) The Last Emperor (1987) Akira (1988) Hotaru no Haka (1988) Tonari no Totoro (1988) Le grand bleu (1988) Balance (1989, short movie) The Silence of the Lambs (1991) Groundhog Day (1993) Forrest Gump (1994) Pulp Fiction (1994) Face/Off (1997) L.A. Have fun!

Just one film? Monty Python's Life of Brian Why? Let me count the ways. It represents Monty Python at the very peak of their considerable comic powers. It is a collection of tonally and thematically diverse sketches by different writers that somehow coheres into a movie that makes sense. It is endlessly quotable (“Spare a shekel for an old ex-leper”, “What have the Romans ever done for us?”, “He's not the Messiah, he's a very naughty boy”, “Stwike him, centurion. Vewy woughly!”, “Welease Bwian!”, “I'm Brian, and so’s my wife.”), it ends with a song (Always Look On The Bright Side Of Life) that has become the signature tune of tough times, at least for Brits.  You should see it because of the controversy. Religious groups tried to ban and boycott it, claiming blasphemy. It's actually very respectful of Christian mythology, but in showing the life of a man that parallels that of Jesus, from being born in the stable next door to ending with a crucifixion, and - perhaps more importantly - lampooning how religions form and behave, maybe it cuts too close to the bone. But how can you judge if you haven't seen it? The response to the film inspired a great sketch, in which a different set of comedians, Not The Nine O'clock News, mercilessly skewered the religious attacks on the film by imagining a world in which Python worshippers were upset by a film called General Synod’s Life of Christ.  But most of all, you should see this film because, in addition to being one of the funniest films ever made, it is also one of the most profound. No other film gets so close to showing us all of humanity, perhaps best typified by the scene in which Brian opens his window to find that a huge crowd has gathered, expecting to hear their chosen one dispense wisdom:  And what he says is actually very wise, not that the crowd sees it: “You're all different” “We're all different” “I'm not” “You've got to work things out for yourselves” “We've got to work thing out for ourselves! …Tell us more. ”

There are a lot of movies you could watch that are worth watching. I’m just going to name some of the movies from my favorites list. If you’re looking for something that somehow teach you something, or just blow your mind away, you can watch each one of them, and it’ll be worth every minute spent. So, here we go: The first in my list is: 1. Room (2015)  Everything about is this movie is just perfect, the plot, acting, directing and it makes some very interesting points. People call it boring a lot, but it isn’t. Everything about this movie is just beautiful, and is one of my favorite movies ever made. 2. Arrival (2016)  This is a movie about what would actually happen when aliens arrive and yeah, they don’t attack the US in this movie. It’s all about communication and it’s ending is one of the best you’d have ever seen 3. Inside Out and Wall-E (Both are my favorite animated movies)   Both are something you will love watching and I assure you, you’d have never seen something like this. Wall-E makes some very interesting points about what would happen if earth ended in the second half, how technology would take us over. And Inside out is yet another masterpiece that basically deals with emotions, both are worth watching. Honorable mention: Up Another masterpice by Pixar, shows us what true love really is, and the whole love story of Carl and Ellie is shown in the first few minutes of the movie, and it does it something in the first 10 minutes that Twilight could never do :p 4. Ex Machina (2013)  One of the best AI movies I’ve seen so far, it’s visually stunning and has a very good story, with the ending you’d not see coming. 5. Interstellar (2013)  A masterpiece by Christopher Nolan, a director you’ve probably heard of.. It’s story makes very good points about how the manking isn’t supposed to die on earth, and how we’re explorers.. And the ending! It’ll leave you speechless! I assure you that. There are a lot of other movies you could watch that you won’t regret. I’ll just name a few more of them without giving an explanation: Gravity (2013)Forrest GumpOnceBefore Trilogy ( Best romantic trilogy I’ve seen) includes: Before Sunrise (1995) and Before Sunset and Before MidnightKimi No Na Wa - Your Name - It’s an anime, if you’re not into animes, maybe this is the place to start.If you want some more recommendations, message me and I’ll provide you with some more names.

Must-watch depends really on your taste as well as on the experience you have regarding movie-watching. If you are new to Hollywood movies - it’s better to watch some descent movies first before upping the game to watch extra-ordinary out-of-the-world experience. Some of the extra-ordinary movies go way over your head because they are too metaphorical and one needs to first understand the movie-culture of Hollywood first. A little background: I love movies and theater. Growing up my parents took us to the movies once a week. I have three university degrees in theater and am a professional director and professor. I go to movies to Like the movie. I don’t start analyzing a film until after I have seen it. In the past year I’ve seen 25 films in the theater and over twice that many in other formats. My 7 favorite INTERESTING films seen in 2017 in the theater (not in order): BABY DRIVER - A joy to watch; pure entertainment; Ansel Elgort is amazing. MOONLIGHT - The story is compelling, about a drug dealer who takes a boy under his protection. Their relationship is symbiotic, they both enable the other to become better individuals. Also deals with how a young gay man comes to terms with his sexuality within a culture ruled extensively by “machismo”. SILENCE - In the 17th Century, two Dutch Catholic priests travel secretly to Japan to learn the fate of their beloved mentor in the face of a society which has condemned all Catholics who do not recant their religion to death. WONDER WOMAN - Finally an excellent superhero movie about a central female character. Good script, good visuals, great characters. SPIDER-MAN: Homecoming - (my personal favorite Marvel character in all three iterations) Tom Holland makes the role his own as a believable high school kid trying to do the impossible while he tries to prove his self-worth. Best villain ever, sympathetic, well developed, skillfully played by veteran Michael Keason THE SHAPE OF WATER - a breath-takingly beautiful non-traditional love story set fifty years ago in a film that captures the period while taking advantage of all the best of modern movie-making technology. Sally Hawkins is vulnerable and strong at the same time, Michael Shannon is a great antagonist. It captured my heart and carried me away. MOTHER! - Aronofsky’s “horror film” that has left much of its audience just scratching their heads in a state of shock. This is a parable about the danger and deadliness a drug is the acquisition of fame, which can often take over an individual’s life at the cost of everything. Honorable mention from the entire list of films I saw this year: Kubo and the Two Strings, Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (by far the best science fiction adventure of the year, surpassing both the new Star Wars & Blade Runner 2049), Wind River, Love and Mercy (biopic Brian Wilson of the Beach Boys), Manchester By the Sea, and finally: Kill Your Darlings (about the Beat Poets in college, NYC 1950’s (sex, drugs, but no rock and roll) See everything on this page and you’ll have your own excellent adventure in film over the next few months.

I suspect I will be quite alone on this, but the movies that I find most interesting are those which are slow and require the viewer to do much of the work her/himself. High-action movies of the type that dominate the box office today bore me, and I find my mind switching off from an overload of camera moves, cuts, flashing lights and blasting sound. Among the movies I have enjoyed most profoundly are those which give my brain time to analyze and explore the elements presented. High on my list is Peter Weir's "Picnic at Hanging Rock." It moves as in a dream state, which permits me to saturate my mind on the beauty of Nature and long-past culture norms of 1900. Another is Gus Van Sant's "Gerry." Again, very slow moving and set in a desert of overwhelming beauty. This allows me to consider the ideas discussed between the two principals as my brain absorbs just how immense Nature on earth can be.  David Lean's "Lawrence of Arabia" does much the same thing, but with a bigger plot. Some movies do work through more of a plot, but do it in a way that allows me to consider what will come next and if what I think would be the optimum action will be what the filmmaker chose. One example of this was "Donnie Darko" (the theatrical version), where the dream-state events were so ambiguous that trying to interpret what I was seeing teased many areas of my brain and left me with a satisfied feeling as if I had created it myself. I find much of the same brain-teasing aspects in David Lynch films, particularly "Mulholland Drive." I saw it in the theater, and was so intrigued I went back to resolve more questions. Each time I went back, I would think, "I've got it all now"; but over the course of a few days, my mind would be trying to place some other episode in a resolution context and I would go back again. I could name others, but there so few I've found that satisfy as opposed to annoy, that I buy the DVD to add to my collection, which I should call a film library. For me, these films are classics--works of art to return to again and again.

This should be easy, but when you say the words ‘good movie’ hundreds of films fly into my mind. So with that being said, I’ll try to give you films that are pretty difficult to dislike. Not only are they wonderful pieces of cinema, they are enjoyable as hell too. So as much as I love Jeanne Dielman’s 3 hour long feminist interpretation of a woman doing housework; a film like that will not be on this list. (To make an impossible task more manageable, I chose one from each of the last ten years) Scott Pilgrim vs The World This film is one of the most stylized films ever made. It is hilarious, heartfelt, and impossible to not enjoy. If you don’t feel some urge to clap after the 1-up scene you might want to check your pulse. Moneyball Possibly the perfect underdog sports movie, but also very real. The Avengers Arguably the best comic book film ever made has great characters reading a hilarious script. You’ll certainly like this movie. The Worlds End This is the craziest comedy of the decade. Nothing makes sense and it’s wonderful. Whiplash You can watch this as an underdog sports movie and love it. You can watch this as an art film with something important to say and love it. The Martian It’s funny, it’s exciting, and it is even creative. What’s not too like? La La Land How can you not love this movie? It’s a wonderful romance, hilarious comedy, and arguably the best musical score of the past 20 years. If that ending doesn’t tug at your heartstrings you might want to check your pulse. Get Out A hilarious comedy, scary horror movie, and poignant social commentary was the breakout feature of Jordan Peele. It is also one of the most beloved movies of the decade. The Death of Stalin Who knew one of the funniest comedies of the decade would be about a soviet power struggle. This movie makes that a reality. Knives Out Lastly, this modern take on a whodunnit is one of the most unpredictable films I’ve ever seen. It makes you believe it is going to be a creative twist on the whodunnit, then it flips that on its head to become an even more creative twist on a whodunnit. Have fun exploring!

BRIEF ENCOUNTER – 1945 – movie – directed and written by David Lean – based upon a one act play, “Still Life” by Noel Coward – produced by Noel Coward - players are: Laura (Celia Johnson), Alec (Trevor Howard), Albert (Stanley Holloway), Myrtle (Joyce Carey). We hear Sergei Rachmaninoff’s, Piano Concerto #2, played by Eileen Joyce at fitting moments throughout the film. Movies of this era bring back memories of myself in the 1940’s, sitting in a dark theater, in a small rural town, and watching Hollywood’s version of how normal people lived, dressed and conducted themselves. Life where I was raised, was much, much different. In David Lean’s movie we see Laura coming home from her shopping trip at around 9:00 in the evening. The children are already in bed and she and her husband, who is still dressed in his business suit, share a pot of black coffee. As a wide-eyed kid of 8 years old, I readily accepted that this was normal behavior for people outside the horizons of my small valley confined by the Cascade Mountains. I envisioned that maybe, I’ll live like that someday too. Surprise, surprise… fate stepped in, and such a transmutation did not take place. David Lean has been lauded because he accomplished so much with so little money, and without any of the super stars of the day. The story begins with the two lovers and their painful parting. About 15 minutes later we shift to flashback, and Laura tells their story in voice-over. Shooting took place in the last months of WWII at the Carnforth railway station in Lancashire, which was too far north to be a target for German V2 rockets and therefore the blackout was not observed. Carnforth has kept the features intact as a tribute to the film. Scenes in the Kardomah café and other interiors were shot in a studio. This movie goes down in film history as one of Lean’s most worthwhile directorial efforts. Shortly after WWII Robert Altman’s wife, Kathryn, recalled that Altman happened to wander into the movie by accident. He said that if seemed pretty slow, but within 20 minutes he was in tears. This movie has been nominated as one of the ten greatest films ever made. It is only 83 minutes long, but it will remain with you forever. Only those without a romantic bone in their body could fail to make this one of their favorite movies … look out Casablanca! The story takes place in 1938, in the London suburbs. Two bored, married, middle class people are mutually attracted. They have a deeply emotional affair of the heart that is destined not to be consummated. This movie is a rare examination of the conflicts that arise when love and desire meet the limitations imposed by middle class moral obligation. Everyone who touched this production deserves praise for their contribution in making it such a stunning portrayal of human longing. David Lean, with intuitive insight, cast a woman who looks “ordinary”. Celia Johnson is not some idealized, sultry and intriguing bit of femininity that would make men perk up and gaze with possessive longing as she crossed the room. Trevor Howard grew to become a fine actor, but in this movie David Lean and Noel Coward commented that he had no idea what was going on. He did not understand why he couldn't just take her to a hotel room and bang away. That being true, then it’s a credit to his acting ability because he had us all fooled.Glamorizing these two characters is precisely why the Hallmark Hall of Fame 1974 TV movie remake, with Sophia Loren and Richard Burton, was a dismal failure. I like Burton and Loren but under the direction of Alan Bridges they were unable to match the artful intensity of Johnson and Howard. It has to be disappointing to work on a movie that to all observers is doomed to fail. Bridges managed to strip the original version entirely of the subtle drama imposed by the social constraints of the time. After that movie’s bad reviews in New York, all plans for further distribution were abandoned. Laura: “I’m an ordinary woman… such things don’t happen to an ordinary woman…. I’ve fallen in love.” In 1981 Celia Johnson was created a Dame of the British Empire. She died of a stroke, at her home near Oxford in 1982 at the age of 73. She was to have opened in a play that evening called “The Understanding”. She was best known for the role she played in Lean’s movie. She said that early in her life she realized that she was very plain and unattractive, but she just “thought it would be nice to act… and I that it might be rather wicked”. She was married to Peter Fleming the brother of Ian Fleming… they had a son and two daughters. Noel Coward’s ending is the capstone of this movie. At that time, the middle class was the bulwark of the social norm. Laura and Alec’s capitulation to the standards that ruled their era, regardless of their personal pain, is what is what raised his play to greatness. The old stiff upper lip lived out to its painful conclusion. The on-going success of this story is a tribute to Noel Coward’s talent as a story-teller. It may have been a brief encounter for Laura and Alec but the passions it stirred up lived on in many radio theater adaptions during that era; they stared Stewart Granger, Debora Karr, Ingrid Bergman, Greer Garson, Lilli Palmer, Van Heflin, Olivia de Havilland and Richard Basehart. A new stage adaptation was created from the Coward’s original play and the movie script. This re-write is still being performed today. Coward’s script was later adapted into a well-received opera by 80 year-old Andre Previn in 2009. So, his original play “Still Life” became two movies, numerous radio dramas, a well-received opera and then back to the stage… quite a run. “A Brief Encounter” was banned in Ireland because it was sympathetic to adultery. - Charles O. Slavens

I would like to suggest movies which have some mainstream appeal and would give someone a taste of how cinema can be so different, deep and, something more than just entertainment. The Godfather It’s widely seen as the greatest American film of all time. This movie has great characters, screenplay and an iconic background score. It surely gives a flavour of what great cinema is. Moreover, if you like this film you can explore films similar to this. You can try watching the films of Tarantino, Coen brothers, Scorsese etc. It might also spark an interest in watching classics from all over the world. 2. Amelie  Amelie is a quirky French comedy about a shy girl. This film is very innovative with beautiful cinematography, weird characters and offbeat screenplay. This film is probably the best introduction to foreign films. If you like this film, you can try more eminent foreign films. Moreover, you may get interested in women oriented films and might want to explore more films of an experimental nature like ‘Run Lola Run’. 3. A separation  I absolutely love Iranian films. This is a film which has solidified the eminent position Iranian cinema has on the world stage. They have great directors. This is a simple family drama cum thriller. It gives us a view of urban Iranian life. This film has the one of the best screenplays and editing of this decade. People run after American and European films. That is why I include this. This film changed the way I viewed cinema. I have not been able to stomach anything less than stellar after watching this. If you like this film, you can try watching more International films which got prominence in film festivals. You might want to try out other Iranian directors and also directors who make realistic and naturalistic dramas like Dardene brothers. I have carefully chosen films from different settings and belonging to different genres. These three films can give a flavour of world cinema.

To quote Scott Nehring “You are what you see” I agree with the author as movies have an tremendous impact on our daily life Though the question says five I have Six best movies in this list 1.SHAWSHANK REDEMPTION ‘Fear can make you a prisoner hope can set you free’ Classic movie!! Shows that talent can take you places with proper use of it Andy a prisoner at Shawshank with his skills made all the prison officials come to him for help as he was a successful banker before Movie shows friendship,innocence,creativity.The bond between Red and Andy is indescribable The tunnel he makes through the walls of his cell to escape Shawshank with the help of rock hammer over 19 years and the way he crawls through 500 yards of shit smelling foulness and the fact that he makes Red promise that when he is released that he would visit a specific hayfied and retrieve a package that is buried under is too good this gives Red a cause after he is out he tries to keep that promise “Some birds aren’t meant to be caged their feathers are too bright and when they fly away the part of you know that it was a sin to lock them up” 2.Hidden figures True story based on historical drama not only inspires us but gives a peek into women who succeeded in making a mark in the history. Nothing can beat the feel that you are going to get after watching this movie If you haven’t watched already I definitely suggest you do Three women working at NASA though stumbled upon many obstacles succeed in making history Katherine Johnson when appointed as mathematician for writing research and provinh calculations for space task group continues to surprise them with her intellect and calculations and when she attends pentagon briefings she impresses all the individuals in those briefings with her calculations on go/no go point for the launch they have been working on this scene in the movie makes us see it on repeat. “Find the genius among geniuses” Dorothy Vaughn learns fortran language on her own and helps with IBM who appoint her she becomes NASA’s first African-American supervisor.On frontier of electronic computing she was regarded as one of the most brilliant minds at NASA. Mary Jackson becomes the first African-American women to attend all white high school and succeeds in becoming NASA’s and America’s first female African-American aeronautical engineer 3.The Blind side Excellent performance by Sandra Bullock in portraying Leigh anne tuohy It’s a true story of Michael Oher how his life changes after family of Leigh Anne adopts him And how her families life changes too with oher in it. I like S.J little brother of Michael who makes his goal to train him and sends the astounding video showing Michael’s performance in a game which makes university coaches come looking for him Worth watching movie. 4.Wonder It follows August Pullman nicknamed Auggie a 10 year old boy with Treacher Collins syndrome trying to fit in the world and the movie also shows perspectives of different people related to auggie along with their stories The movie follows how people treat him and how he reacts to them and in doing so how he stands out he is given an award at the end of the movie by the school for being bold and honest boy Great message about kindness,friendship and acceptance Emotional rolercoaster is an best way to describe this movie 5.Dangal This is an real story of a father who was a wrestler and longs for a boy child to make his dream of being a famous wrestler come true instead he is blessed with girls. When his girls put few boys of the school in their position by hitting them he realises that you don’t need a boy to be a wrestler he can turn his girls into wrestlers. He trains his girls with extreme dedication and vigorously not holding back on practice and his girls make him proud by being excellent at their wrestling and proving the opinion of many people in their village and others who thought wrestling is for guys Excellent movie which shows that gender has Nothing to do with ones work when you have talent and do the hard work ur sure to excel in any field u choose :) 6.Gifted hands Ben Carson’s story Movie follows how Ben Carson became a reputated paediatric neurosurgeon. Ben during childhood couldn’t read and lacks in grades.One day his mother while explaining the word he reads out discovers that he has eye sight and couldn’t read properly she gets him a new pair of glasses after that Ben understands what he reads and excels in studies. All the struggles Ben and his mother overcome are depicted in this movie his mother a strong women encourages her kids to study different kind of books and make a report after reading them by the end of the week Her mother sayings like “If you use your time to develop your God given gifts it wouldn’t be long before folks was watching you on Tv” and “You can do anything anybody else can do Bennie only you can do it better” are to good to hear. When Ben teacher asks the class showing them a rock Ben explains it in complete detail that it’s a rock called obsidian how it forms his teacher impressed introduces him to biology by saying he just stepped into whole new world he later receives highest academic achievement in 8th grade continues going to yale university later and decides to become a brain surgeon when he learns what a mysterious and miraculous of an organ brain is that by stimulating one section of an 85 year old you can bring back memories of article read 60 years before,that’s excellent isn’t it!! It astonishingly surprising to learn that 3 pounds of grey matter can do wonders. Movie shows how he succeeds in performing a hemispherectomy surgery on a 4 year kid diagnosed from Rasmussens and suffering from seizures and separating craniopagus twins of Germany I strongly recommend people to watch this movie it’s an excellent one.

This is a very hard question. From thousands of movies, these are the top 5 movies that one must watch for me! ParasiteSchindler's ListWall-EDark KnightThe Silence of the Lamb Possibly one of the hottest movie of the year, Parasite. Critics have praised it unanimously and even considered it one of the best movies of 2010. It is a black comedy thriller that brilliantly highlights current social issues/themes. The movies follows members of a poor family who finesses to become employed by a wealthy family by infiltrating their household and deceiving as highly qualified people that are totally unrelated. Overall this movie will have you glued to the screen and have your heart pounding the entire time.  Schindler’s List is a masterpiece and highly regarded as one of best World War 2 movies ever created. The movie revolves around a Sudeten German businessman Oskar Schindler. Together with his wife, he saves thousands of Polish-Jewish refugees from the holocaust by employing them in his factories. He spends his life savings on bribes, black market goods and foods to keep the refugees alive. Overall this movie is more than a movie. It’s one of the historical dramas of our times and which gives us a glimpse of terrors of war through the eyes of media that we call film.  Now, my one of my all time favorite animated movie: Wall-E. Although it’s a kid’s animation, the movie itself is thought-provoking and entangles a larger picture within the film: environmental issues, corporatism, obesity and consumerism . Wall-E follows a trash compacter robot on a future uninhabited trash-filled earth where it’s left to clean up the mess. While on his mission, he is visited by a probe named EVE and falls in love. He travels across the galaxy in pursuit of EVE and his love. Although there are minimal dialog within the film, the outstanding production within the film allows the viewers to understand through body language and robotic sounds.  The Dark Knight. It’s a modern action classic that broke the walls of corny superhero movies. When I think of Dark Knight, it reminisces me of underground crime fighter fighting within the dark rather than modern superhero films with gimmicky action scenes and graphics. The movie portrays Batman, District Attorney Harvery Dent and Police Lieutenant James Gordon teaming up to eliminate organized crime within Gotham City. However this effort gets turned upside down when the Joker starts to contest.  The Silence of the Lambs is rather a classic. It ranked top 5 in the thriller category at The American Film Institute. Being a psychological horror thriller, The film focuses on an FBI trainee, named Clarice Starling, who gets pulled out of training to go after a psychotic killer named Buffalo Bill, who not only kills his victims but also skins them. Not sure where to start, Clarice goes on to get the help of a cannibalistic serial killer/ psychiatrist Hannibal Lecter. The overall theme and setting are so mesmerizing that it will have your heart pouncing and keep you on your toes. This movie is regarded as one of the best movies ever made in this category and you would not regret watching this. If you’re still having trouble looking for recommendations for movies or simply want to search around what kind movies there are, I highly recommend using an app called Maimovie. It’s an AI taste finder app where it recommends a list of movies for you by simply saying asking phrases like “What are the 5 best movies one must watch?”.

Here Are Some Must Watch Hollywood Films ☺ (1) Citizen Kane (1941) The Orson Welles directed drama film follows the story of a publishing tycoon and his scandalous life and is a must watch.  (2) Ben-Hur (1959) This 1959 epic historical drama film directed by William Wyler is the most recognisable classic on slavery, war and revenge.  (3) The Shining (1980) Which list is complete without Stanley Kubrik ? His 1980 horror classic starring Jack Nicholson first bombed at the box office but soon became critics' and researchers' favourite.  (4) The Deer Hunter (1978) The American epic war drama co-written and directed by Michael Cimino stars Robert de Niro, Christopher Walken and a host of splendid actors playing roles set against the backdrop of the Vietnam War.  (5) The Great Dictator (1940) A political satire comedy-drama film written, directed, produced and scored by and starring Charlie Chaplin, The Great Dictator probably doesn't need any introduction. Just watch it already.  (6) Life Is Beautiful (1997) Directed by and starring Roberto Benigni, Life Is Beautiful is a tragic comedy of a Jewish father and son's journey through life in the Nazi camps.  (7) There Will Be Blood (2007) The Daniel Day-Lewis starrer follows the twisted story of an oil tycoon and his grand pursuit towards monopoly.  (8) The Godfather (1972) The first essential on the list is obviously the Francis Ford Coppola classic, The Godfather, starring Marlon Brando and Al Pacino in their most memorable roles in movie history.  (9) Psycho (1960) The Alfred Hitchcock classic follows the story of deranged Norman Bates (Anthony Perkins) and his psychopathic escapades.  (10) Apocalypse Now (1979) Directed by Francis Ford Coppola, Apocalypse Now is an epic adventure war film set during the Vietnam War and one of film history's greatest classics.  (11) Pulp Fiction (1994) Directed by Quentin Tarantino, Pulp Fiction is considered to be one of his best works and one of the best movies of all time.  (12) The Exorcist (1973) Directed by William Friedkin and based on William Peter Blatty novel, The Exorcist has been dubbed as one of the scariest horror films of all time.  (13) Gladiator (2000) The Ridley Scott movie is based on the life of a Roman general turned gladiator (Russell Crowe) and his fight for freedom.  (14) The Lord Of The Rings Series (estd. 2001) Based on the fantasy epic series by J R R Tolkien, The Lord Of The Rings series needs to be checked off of your movie list if it already hasn't.  (15) The Wrestler (2008) Directed by Darren Aronofsky and starring Mickey Rourke who plays a wrestler as he tries to keep with his life's struggles with family and his career.  (16) Star Wars Series (estd. 1977) This George Lucas produced saga doesn't require much explanation. 'Nuff said.  (17) Schindler's List (1993) Directed by Steven Spielberg, Schindler's List is the real story based on the work of Nazi Czech business man Oskar Schindler, who saved over 1100 Jews from execution, which is why we suggest everyone to watch it.  (18) Fight Club (1999) Based on the 1996 novel by Chuck Palahniuk and directed by David Fincher, Fight Club stars Brad Pitt and Edward Norton in a head-scratching psychological thriller.  (19) Forrest Gump (1994) The movie follows the story of Forrest (Tom Hanks), a low IQ man, and his extraordinary journey through love, war and life.  (20) The Good, the Bad and the Ugly (1966) Directed by Sergio Leone and starring Clint Eastwood, the film follows the story of an unlikely alliance between two bounty hunters in search of a buried treasure. I have been blown away by the stuff being made in Italy at the moment. Here are two of the best films I’ve ever seen as of late. I challenge you to watch either of the two trailers below and not give serious consideration into watching them… both of these were quite an experience:  Film Title: Suburra (“Slums”) Release Date: 2015 Genre(s): Crime, Drama, Thriller Director: Stefano Sollima Premise: An Italian gangster has plans to transform Rome’s waterfront into the equivalent of Las Vegas (United States). The local mob bosses come together for this common goal in agreement of all the potential business that would ensue. But as this plan starts to roll into action, suddenly everything begins to fall apart. Teaser/Trailer:  YouTube (Source) | Suburra Official Trailer Why Should I Watch This? As of late there have been quite a number of great films coming out of Italy. I’m extremely grateful considering the garbage being made here in the United States at the moment… This one was quite the breath of fresh air. Striking visuals, strong cast, amazing acting, outstanding soundtrack …and did I mention the breathtaking visuals?  Film Title: La Grande Bellezza (“The Great Beauty”) Release Date: 2013 Genre(s): Drama Director: Paolo Sorrentino Premise: Journalist Jep Gambardella has charmed and seduced his way through the lavish nightlife of Rome for decades. Since the legendary success of his one and only novel, he has been a permanent fixture in the city’s literary and social circles. Teaser/Trailer:  YouTube (Source) | La Grande Bellezza Official Trailer Why Should I Watch This? Packed with breathtaking visuals and a strong soundtrack interlaced over top. It felt like a piece of art, or a fine painting that we are watching the director make. You aren’t sure what is they are ultimately creating until the credits role. Be warned that this movie utilizes a great deal of symbolism throughout which makes for a less traditional script (something not seen in the U.S. very often). I suspect that any of you movie buffs out there will truly appreciate the kind of material that Sorrentino has become famed for (e.g. Youth (2015) which I also highly recommend).

This is such an open question, it hurts just starting to think how to begin to answer :) I presume you’re not a movie buff, but a neophyte that wants to get a real kick out of a 90 minutes sitting on the couch. So, to start, and very important, you don’t have to watch anything you don’t like. If a movie does not carry you into its universe in the first 15 minutes, it’s not a good movie. At least for you, at least at the time you try to watch it. Watching movies is a “cheap thrill”, and if you like B series movies, that’s fine. If you get into watching art movies, that’s fine, too. Nobody can tell you what to like. As a corollary, you can’t start by watching art movies. Tarkovsky, for example, cannot be digested if you didn’t watch “lighter” movies before and come to a point where you want more. It’s like French cheese, you have to develop a taste for it. Here’s an eclectic list - far from being a must or an exhaustive one (I’ve tried to do a list of 10, then 20, then 30… :). It’s just a start of good movies, that I’ve personally enjoyed and still do. They are not in any specific order, and the common quality I find they have is that they have the capability of transporting you in their universe fairly quick. Most are “commercial” movies, which is a category apart from “art” movies. From here, take the road of Directors that you find interesting. Some good ones: Almodovar, Tarantino, Oliver Stone, Alejandro Jodorowsky, Wes Anderson, etc, etc. Then some French ones (the French invented the cinema, after all): Jacques Tati, Francois Truffaut, Luc Besson, Francois Ozon, and the list can go on and on. So: Good Will HuntingTaxi DriverPulp FictionThe Green MileThe Deer HunterPlatoonSchindler’s ListSaving Private RyanEnemy at the GateThe Silence of the LambsForrest GumpTrue Grit (the one directed by the Coen Brothers in 2010)Inglorious Basterds (not a misspell :)Django UnchainedThe Dark KnightNo Country for Old MenThe MatrixThe DepartedAvatarPan’s LabyrinthSlumdog MillionaireDistrict 9City of GodThe Life of OthersMillion Dollar BabyKill BillSin CityCatch Me If You CanThe Curious Case of Benjamin Button4 Months 3 Weeks and 2 DaysThe Secret in Their EyesAmores PerrosY Tu Mama TambienMan on FireAmerican GangsterMoonrise KingdomJour de Fete

1. Joker 》 Joker Story: The origin tale of the Joker (Joaquin Phoenix) – one of the most iconic villains in comic book history. Joker Review: Arthur Fleck (Joaquin Phoenix) isn’t happy with his life. He struggles to make money as a part-time clown while sharing a rundown apartment with his ailing mom (Frances Conroy). But Arthur lives in a city struck by hard times where a decent, honest living is difficult to come by. He also suffers from a condition that causes him to break into uncontrollable laughter. None of this stops Arthur from dreaming big. He aspires to be a stand-up comedian and attempts to write jokes in his diary. Caught in between it all, Arthur slowly begins to lose his grip on sanity. It’s immediately apparent that this is not your standard comic book fare. Todd Phillips painstakingly constructs the story of a man at his wit’s end when pushed beyond his breaking point. Phillips doesn’t glorify mental illness but instead makes a compelling case of a deeply disturbed individual struggling to find a coping mechanism in the form of an unhinged alter ego. This also resonates in his gritty vision of Gotham City, a metropolis brought to its knees, and crime is just a way of life. Only the rich and corrupt seem to be unaffected by the mayhem – a pertinent notion in present times. Set in the early 80's, this fictional city is reminiscent of that era with impeccable production and a time-relevant, yet unsettling soundtrack that evokes a constant sense of uneasiness. Arthur Fleck’s gradual descent into madness has a distant parallel to ‘Taxi Driver’, also featuring Robert De Niro, so there’s a sense of joy for the cinephile to see him here. But, none of the cast holds a candle to Joaquin Phoenix in the titular role, captured by a dedicated and immersive performance. Watching Phoenix disappear into character makes one fear the actor’s sanity as he creates his own unique version of the villain. At first, his wiry, awkward frame stumbles to get from one place to the next, but when he eventually transforms, he becomes graceful, resembling an agile dancer. It’s simultaneously difficult to watch and yet, impossible to take your eyes off him. If Joaquin Phoenix finally wins an Academy Award for this performance, it will be hard to argue against it. Disturbing and intense, yet undeniably brilliant, this may very well become the definitive origin tale of the Joker. 2. Donnie Darko (2001)  Donnie Darko is an American science fiction psychological thriller drama film written and directed by Richard Kelly, and stars Jake Gyllenhaal. One to fry your brain.  3. The Wrestler (2008)  Directed by Darren Aronofsky and starring Mickey Rourke who plays a wrestler as he tries to keep with his life's struggles with family and his career.  4. Rear Window (1954)  Directed by Alfred Hitchcock, Rear Window follows the story of photographer stuck in an apartment who begins to spy on his neighbours to find a shocking revelation. 5. Burn After Reading (2008)  A black comedy film written, produced, edited and directed by Joel and Ethan Coen, Burn After Reading is a hilarious film following two friends who attempt to black mail a CIA agent. Thanks For Watching. . Don't Forget To Upvote And Follow 》》》

1. The Godfather (1972)  Well, if Stanley Kubrick described it as "possibly the greatest movie ever made," who is anyone else to argue? Francis Ford Coppola's gangster-movie-redefining adaptation of Mario Puzo's Mafia novel is the Empire Greatest Movies Poll No. 1 incumbent, and for a very good reason. It sits right at the juncture between 'classic' and 'modern' cinema; it feels respectably venerable, while at the same time vibrant and vital — not a dry, cinematic relic that you feel obliged to bow before, but a hot-blooded, living god that you embrace. 2. Star Wars: Episode V — The Empire Strikes Back (1980)  The original “this one’s darker” sequel, and by far the strongest of the saga. Not just because the baddies win (temporarily), or because it Force-slammed us with that twist (“No, I am your father”). Empire super-stardestroys thanks to the way it deepens the core relationships — none more effectively than Han and Leia’s. She loves him. He knows. And it still hurts. 3. The Dark Knight (2008)  Easily as influential on the genre as that other summer ’08 comic-book movie, Iron Man, Christopher Nolan’s Batman sequel works wonders because he never saw it as a superhero film. It’s closer to a Michael Mann crime epic — except instead of Pacino and De Niro in a diner, you get a bloke dressed as a bat and a psychotic clown in a police interrogation room. With, er, Aaron Eckhart as Val Kilmer... 4. The Shawshank Redemption (1994)  The warm, leathery embrace of Morgan Freeman’s narration... The reassuringly Gary Cooper-ish rumple of Tim Robbins’ face... Odd that a movie which features such harshness and tragedy should remain a feel-good perennial — even odder when you consider it was a box-office flop on release. Few directorial debuts are so deftly constructed; no surprise, then, that Frank Darabont’s yet to top it. 5. Pulp Fiction (1994)  If Reservoir Dogs was a blood-spattered calling card, Pulp Fictionsaw Quentin Tarantino kick our front door off its hinges — and then get applauded for doing it with such goddamn panache. It wore its numerous influences on its sleeve (from The Great Train Robbery to Psycho via Kiss Me Deadly and Karate Kiba) and yet felt utterly, invigoratingly fresh and new. We happy? Yeah, we happy.

While a lot of people will talk about a lot of popular and amazing movies, which are all very very very good, I will talk about one movie which I watched yesterday and it was just super-brilliant, unbelievable art and the work of a genius IMHO. That movie is “Adaptation”.  So, whats so special about Adaptation. Well, you have to watch it to know, because from the very first scene, it grabs your attention with Nicholas Cage’s monologue on a dark screen and does not let go until the very last scene, which is an amazing fast motion video of flowers blooming against a mundane LA road. The actors in the movie are - Nicholas Cage - Who plays a double role so well that I almost forgot that it was the same actor and only remembered later that night when I was having dinner.Meryl Streep - Who looks so lovely and portrays so much sadness in her eyes, it breaks your heartChris Cooper - Who plays an obscure hygienically challenged genius. And what is he a genius of?? Horticulture!! Go figure!! (oh, btw, he won an Oscar that this role)SPOILER ALERT And the dialogues in the movie!! Oh the dialogue!! You are what you love, not what loves you, I decided that a long time ago.I suppose I do have one unembarrassed passion. I want to know how it feels like to care about something passionately.By simply doing what they are designed to do, something large and magnificent happens. In this sense they show us how to live. How the only barometer you have is your heart. How when you spot your flower, you can't let anything get in your way.And the sequences - The one where John Laroche describes the different types of OrchidsThe one where Susan Orlean imagines the Ghost OrchidThe one where Susan Orlean imitates a phone ring-toneThe one in the bar with Charles Kauffman and Robert McKeeAlmost all the scenes where both Charles and Donald Kauffman are presentAdaptation is one of the most beautiful, evocative and marvelous piece of genius story-telling, an unbelievably artistic film, I have ever seen and I know I an going to see it a lot more time in the future. And, if you have watched it and loved it, I join your tribe and if not, for heavens sake, watch it!!!

Here are five movies I've watched somewhat recently*. They are not necessarily my favorites**, but these came to mind… In Bruges  Two Irish hitmen (Colin Farrell and Brendan Gleeson) hide out in the picturesque Flemish town, awaiting orders from their boss (Ralph Fiennes). An engaging mix of hilarity and heartbreak ensues. In my opinion this is Farrell’s best performance by a longshot. The Nice Guys  A tough-guy-for-hire (Russel Crowe) and an unscrupulous private eye (Ryan Gosling) team up to investigate the mysterious death of a pornstar in ’70s Los Angeles. Includes such comedic gems as the following: Gosling’s Teenage Daughter: “Dad, there's, like, whores and stuff here.” Gosling: “What have I told you about saying ‘and stuff’? Just say ‘there are whores here’.” King Arthur: Legend of the Sword  This movie got terrible reviews, but I enjoyed it. Charlie Hunnam is tolerable as Arthur, and Jude Law is great as the evil King Vortigern, but Guy Ritchie's signature directing style takes this film from ‘average’ to ‘pretty good’. I liked his depiction of 5th century London as a rundown but formerly opulent Roman city, a Dark Age Detroit if you will. Dunkirk  The great Christopher Nolan tells three vaguely intertwining stories of the evacuation of Allied forces from the eponymous French city as the Nazis close in. Not a lot of dialogue, but a very well-crafted film. Baby Driver  A perpetually earbudded young man named Baby works as a getaway driver for criminals in Atlanta. John Hamm and Jamie Foxx are great as two of the crooks, but sadly Kevin Spacey’s talent is underutilized. Now blow off whatever it is you’re supposed to be doing and watch five movies in a row! *I watch In Bruges every few months. **In Bruges is absolutely one of my favorites.

According to me, five films that are a must watch are:- Shawshank redemption:- This film is a must watch for the people who are battling with depression as it will give them a ray of hope to live. The film teaches you to think out of the box during dire circumstances. Even if you're not depressed and are dealing with any other problem in your life, you should watch this film.  Chichhore:- This film teaches you to deal with failures. It also puts forth a message that life is beyond the realm of failures and sucesses. Life is not about winning nor losing, it is about living each day to the fullest.You might not have fond memories of scoring good marks in your class but you’d definitely have for the moments you had spent with your friends.  Pink:- This film is a must watch for all the women who have faced any sort of harassment in their life. It gives them courage to raise their voice against the people who have been treating them badly. In a society where every minute a woman is molested, this film is a must watch as it gives courage to the women to fight for justice. It conveys a message that when woman says NO she means NO.  Anand:- Just like the two aforementioned films( 1 and 2) this one is also a slice of life film. The film revolves around a man who knows that his going to day in a couple of months. He lives each day as if it were his last day. The film teaches you to value your life, to live in the moment without giving too much thought about the future. The film has a dialogue Zindagi lambi nahi, badi honi chahiye which means It doesn’t matter how many days you have in your life, what matters is how much life you have in your days.  URI:- This film will instill a sense patriotism in you. The film is about shows how India retaliated to the Balakot air strikes. The scene in which they give tribute to the soldier who gets martyred will bring chills down your spine. I wonder why didn't I miss on such a gem of movie before( however I did mention in my previous post on the same topic).  Besides these movies, the other movies that are a must watch are Chak De India, Rang De Basanti, Masaan, Swades, Black, Prestige, Black and Paa.

Super Dark Times Faithfully channeling the spirit of its influences (Stephen King, Steven Spielberg, River’s Edge, Donnie Darko) rather than indulging in nostalgic shout-outs, Kevin Phillips’s Super Dark Times digs deeply into adolescent male dynamics, only to unearth horrifying truths about teen boys’ capacity for chaos. Bolstered by a uniformly excellent young cast, Phillips’ feature concerns an accidental tragedy that befalls four friends (Owen Campbell, Charlie Tahan, Max Talisman, and Sawyer Barth), and the subsequent cover-up that strains not only their relationships but the former duo’s romantic bond with a classmate (Elizabeth Cappucino). An opening sequence involving a deer breaking into a school sets an appropriate doom-laden mood, which Phillips expertly amplifies while simultaneously capturing a very real, complex sense of budding masculine desire, confusion, and rage. It’s one of the year’s standout debuts, and though it’s set in the mid-1990s, its snapshot of impotence and fury resonates as both universal—and terribly timely John Wick: Chapter 2 Rarely has a film seemed less in need of a sequel than 2014's John Wick, a self-contained bit of action-cinema perfection. Nonetheless, John Wick: Chapter 2manages to thrill through a constant barrage of masterful gun-fu carnage, with bullets flying at a jaw-dropping rate courtesy of Keanu Reeves' nattily dressed assassin. Director David Leitch's follow-up is a symphonic orgy of frenzied firearm warfare, with violence here depicted as a culinary art form performed by stylish Zen badasses with philosophical souls. It's akin to a hybrid of Jean-Pierre Melville's noir cool and Marvel's superhero fantasy, all underworld rules and regulations and unbelievable feats of fearsome brutality, with Reeves exuding male-model chicness and powder-keg explosiveness as the epicenter of this murderous maelstrom. While the film's reason for once again forcing Wick out of retirement isn't nearly as gripping as its predecessor's vengeance-for-his-dead-dog motivation, the specifics of Chapter 2 wind up mattering little in the face of so much exhilarating death and destruction. Having been professional in their work it seems to be a easy task for them. Your jaw drops after seeing the capabilities of the old blind man. The title suites the movie.Better watch this thriller if you are having a boring day. You might feel sick after watching this movie but definitely you'll love it. 4. A Quite Place  Wouldn't you like to a quite room when you've got too much of stuff to do or maybe you might find peace in one. Imagine being in a town where it's prohibited to utter a single word. What's happens when you talk? You die. The story revolves after a happy family having been adjusted in this ungodly place. As expected they end up in a situation where they keep their lifes' at stake. But what haunts you is the after effects. This movie will be remembered for a long time. 5. Hera Pheri  It's one of the best comedy movies of Bollywood. It's the right movie if you love to watch something light. You'll be mesmerized with the characters. It's one of the evergreen hit's of Bollywood. Yeah it's better to watch the prequel before catching into this one. You'll be fixed with laughter I guarantee.

“Forrest Gump” and “No Country for Old Men”. These movies illustrate some very profound realities about the Human condition. “Forrest Gump”, I didn't realize what I was watching, when I first saw that movie. But as a Christian, I have for the past 10 plus years, been learning and coming to understand just how complete, God's control of everything in the whole universe actually is. During this period of time, I would watch reruns of this movie and could see that the entire movie was based on that reality. From the floating feather in the opening sequence, which ends up settling in at the foot of Forrest Gump (seemingly by chance), to the closing sequence of that same feather taking to the sky again (out of the book that Forrest saved it in), and everything in between. The whole movie was about some guy “Forrest Gumping” his way through life. The movie depicts what I have learned from my studying of God's Word (The Bible) and my own journey through this life on planet earth. I have a brief statement of faith, that I have come to in recent times, stating what I believe is “True Reality” : The God of the Bible is the Sovereign Creator of, Ruler of, and Owner of, every molecule in existence everywhere and for all eternity. *************************************** Creator of Genesis 1:1 NASB In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth. John 1:1-5 NASB In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God. [2] He was in the beginning with God. [3] All things came into being through Him, and apart from Him nothing came into being that has come into being. [4] In Him was life, and the life was the Light of men. [5] The Light shines in the darkness, and the darkness did not comprehend it. Colossians 1:15-17 NASB He is the image of the invisible God, the firstborn of all creation. [16] For by Him all things were created, both in the heavens and on earth, visible and invisible, whether thrones or dominions or rulers or authorities-all things have been created through Him and for Him. [17] He is before all things, and in Him all things hold together. *************************************** Ruler of Psalm 103:19 NASB The LORD has established His throne in the heavens, And His sovereignty rules over all. Psalm 139:16 NASB Your eyes have seen my unformed substance; And in Your book were all written The days that were ordained for me, When as yet there was not one of them. *************************************** Owner of Psalm 50:10-12 NASB "For every beast of the forest is Mine, The cattle on a thousand hills."I know every bird of the mountains, And everything that moves in the field is Mine."If I were hungry I would not tell you,For the world is Mine, and all it contains. Proverbs 24:12 NASB If you say, "See, we did not know this," Does He not consider it who weighs the hearts? And does He not know it who keeps your soul? And will He not render to man according to his work? Ezekiel 18:4 NASB Behold, all souls are Mine; the soul of the father as well as the soul of the son is Mine. The soul who sins will die. *************************************** Or as the movie put it : "I don't know if Momma was right or if ... if it's Lieutenant Dan. I don't know if we each have a destiny, or if we're all just floating around accidental-like on a breeze, but I ... I think maybe it's both. Maybe both is happening at the same time." - Forrest Gump (1994) “No Country for Old Men”, this movie seems to focus on the same question of life being fate or blind chance. It is a much darker & pessimistic view of life than the more positive “Forrest Gump”. Although each movie portrays both quality character traits as well as negative traits (to the extreme with the hit man Anton Chigurh). Pride and Humility seems to be the actual topics of these 2 movies! Chigurh is pride run amok and Forrest is humility in every conceivable situation in life. I ask a lot of questions and now at 63 years old, I find that the questions all seem to come together into “The One Thing” (a quote from the “No Country…” movie. I believe that 1 thing is how we respond to God, in every possible situation & circumstances that we “make” or “find” ourselves in. We can act in self centered, evil, sinful pride? or we can humble ourselves and act according to what God has told us in the Bible : Micah 6:6-8 NASB With what shall I come to the LORD And bow myself before the God on high? Shall I come to Him with burnt offerings, With yearling calves? [7] Does the LORD take delight in thousands of rams, In ten thousand rivers of oil? Shall I present my firstborn for my rebellious acts, The fruit of my body for the sin of my soul? [8] He has told you, O man, what is good; And what does the LORD require of you But to do justice, to love kindness, And to walk humbly with your God?

Argo: Argo is a 2010 film based 1979 Iran attacks on the US embassy. It is adapted on the book “The master of Disguise”. Affleck stars as Tony, who creates a fake movie to be shot in Tehran. He then assembles a fake crew and a fake production house. All this whilst knowing that no credit will be given to him for the work he did. The way Affleck portrays the character is astounding. He plays it cool and calm, whilst building suspense. The best part about Argo is, you know the ending of the film. But you do not know how they will reach to that place. There is suspense and tension everywhere. That’s what makes it a edge of the seat thriller. Additionally, the film wonderfully weaved the characters into a not very complicated story. The producers and makeup folks managed to really capture the look of the era and look of the actual characters in real life. The Intouchables: A french biographical tale starring Omar Sy and Francois Cluzet, the film is about a wealthy aristocrat and his friendship with a low level immigrant. When the rich man becomes a Quadriplegic following an accident, an unusual friendship develops between the him and the immigrant he hires to take care of himself. The film is exceedingly good and well made. It makes you cry, laugh and become emotional. The film is an emotional journey which shows money cannot bring you happiness and it’s the people around you that count more. A remake is also made in Indian Language (titled Oopiri). Both are equally good and heart touching.  Blade RunnerRidley Scott’s Perfection can be seen in this dystopian movie where Synthetics are part of everyday life. However, they develop a Conscience and starts to question their creator. There are certain scenes in the film like Cops chasing one down the alley, the conversation between Harrison Ford and the creator, which are plain delight to watch. Stunning visuals like the (pyramid shown) in the film are a mark of the directors creativity. This movie is regarded as one of the greatest movie of all time and the legendary Christopher Nolan Quotes this movie as the greatest movie of all time. No wonder.  it is a must watch for each and everyone of those fan around
