(1953), Calle Mayor (1956), Chimes at Midnight (1965), The Spirit of the Beehive (1973), Surcos (1951) andLa Caza (The Hunt, 1966) Sri Lanka See also: Cinema of Sri Lanka Pura Handa Kaluwara (1997), also known as Death on a Full Moon Day, directed by P. Vithanage and starring Joe Abeywickrama, topped the British Film Institute's poll of "Top 10 Sri Lankan Films" of all time.[296]Ananta Rathiriya (1995), directed by P. Vithanage, topped the user poll of "Top 10 Sri Lankan Films" of all time.[297]Sweden See also: Cinema of Sweden Persona (1966): Acclaimed director Ingmar Bergman's movie reached the highest position (#5 in 1972) of any Swedish film on any of Sight & Sound's lists of greatest films of all time.[citation needed]The Phantom Carriage (Körkarlen, 1921), directed by Victor Sjöström, was selected as the best Swedish film of all time by the film magazine FLM in 2012.[298]Raven's End (Kvarteret Korpen, 1963), directed by Bo Widerberg, was chosen by Nöjesguiden as the best Swedish film ever in 1995.[299]Taiwan See also: Cinema of Taiwan A City of Sadness (traditional Chinese: 悲情城市) came in at #5, the highest ranking Taiwanese film, on a list of Best 100 Chinese Motion Pictures unveiled by the Hong Kong Film Awards .Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon (traditional Chinese: 臥虎藏龍) is a 2000 wuxia film directed by Ang Lee and co-produced by Taiwan, Hong Kong, the United States andChina. The highest grossing foreign-language film in American history, it won over 40 awards, including the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film (for Taiwan) and 3 other Academy Awards.Turkey See also: Cinema of Turkey Yol (1982), directed by Şerif Gören, was selected as the best Turkish film in a 2003 poll undertaken by Ankara Sinema Derneği (Ankara Association for Cinema Culture) of people interested in cinema professionally.[300]Ukraine See also: Cinema of Ukraine Земля (Earth), one of the World's twelve greatest films of all time (Brussels World's Fair, 1958).[301][302]Пропала грамота (The Lost Letter), was banned in Soviet Union. 20 years later was awarded with Golden Pagoda during the Bangkok International Film Festival, 1991.Тіні забутих предків (Shadows of Forgotten Ancestors) received the British Academy Award and Grand Prix at Mar del Plata International Film Festival (1965)United Kingdom See also: Cinema of the United Kingdom The Third Man (1949): Voted best British film ever by members of the British Film Institute in 1999.[303] Highest ranked British entry on the Rotten Tomatoes list of the best films of all time, and #2 overall.[304]Lawrence of Arabia (1962): voted "best British film of all time" in August 2004 by a London Sunday Telegraph poll of Britain's leading filmmakers.[305] (See also: Epic above).Get Carter (1971): Named best British film in a poll of 25 film critics by Total Film magazine in 2004.[306]Don't Look Now (1973): Named best British film in a poll of 150 film industry experts conducted by Time Out London in 2011.[307]Monty Python and the Holy Grail (1975) was voted the best British picture of all time by a 2004 poll by the UK arm of Amazon and Internet Movie Database.[92]United States See also: Cinema of the United States, National Film Registry, and American Film Institute Since 1998, the American Film Institute has assembled juries of film community leaders and polled them for a series of top 100 lists. Two of the lists from the series, 100 Years... 100 Movies from 1998 and 100 Years... 100 Movies (10th Anniversary Edition) from 2007, identified Citizen Kane as the best American film ever. In other years, AFI's jury members selected Some Like It Hot the greatest American comedy, Psycho as the most thrilling American movie, Casablanca as the greatest American love story, Singin' in the Rain as the greatest American film musical, and It's a Wonderful Life as the most inspiring American film. [308] In 1977, a poll of the AFI membership saw Gone with the Wind in first place. [309] Citizen Kane (1941) was selected as the greatest American film in 2015 by sixty-two international film critics surveyed by the BBC.[310] It was also ranked top in every Sight & Sound critics' poll between 1962 and 2002, and the directors' poll in 1992 and 2002.[311]Vertigo (1958) topped the Sight & Sound critics' poll in 2012, dethroning Citizen Kane at the top of the critics' poll for the first time in 50 years since 1962. It has also been voted #8 in the directors' poll.[3]The Godfather (1972) was selected as the greatest film by industry professionals in a Hollywood survey undertaken by The Hollywood Reporter in 2014.

Hands down, 2001: A Space Odyssey is my must see film for everyone. It is sheer brilliance: a heroic epic poem presented through a camera lens and studio mics accompanied by a faultless soundtrack. 2001 is a transubstantiation from one form of art into another with nothing lost during the transition. It has influenced sci-fi and movie culture ever since, from Star Wars to Buzz Lightyear in Toy Story. And no, you do not have to “understand” it to appreciate and enjoy it. Special effects, modelling and make-up were way ahead of the times. Like any work of art, “A poem need not mean/But it must Be.” Quite famously, as Rock Hudson left the initial screening of the film, he remarked, “Can anyone tell me what the hell that is that we just saw?” This is often the reaction of an initiate. They expect a story, and they get one—a brilliant and original story. But they do not yet know how to read it. This is not the fault of the film.

That’s really hard to answer because there are so many wonderful movies out there from throughout the century. But I’ll put down three that I can think of at the top of my head. Get Out This is one of the best movies I’ve seen in 2017. Hands down. It speaks to social issues in so many levels. I seriously think this will be a film that will be dissected in cinema class for up-and-coming filmmakers in the years to come. 2. Life is Beautiful  Don’t get hung up on the subtitles. This is one of those movies that will bring you to tears. Each and every time. It has such deep substance that I think you’ll forget you’re reading the subtitles. 3. The Passion of the Christ  Doesn’t matter if you’re religious or not. And yeah, maybe Mel Gibson did direct it and he isn’t the most popular person in Hollywood. That being said, this film is close depiction of what Jesus Christ went through at the cross. Keep in mind that He didn’t just die for the sake of dying at the hands of the Romans, he offered himself up so that he would take the sins of the world, our sins, and raise from the dead three days later. It’s graphic and horrific, the scenes, but it shows what he endured for us. You may not be Christian, but it’s at least something to appreciate. And you are Christian, you know that this was God in the flesh suffering for us.

The movie that comes to my mind first is ***The Shawshank Redemption.  The main reason behind this being that the movie is rated No.1 in IMDb with a rating of 9.2. It is also a brilliant movie with a fantastic performances from the leads Morgan Freeman,Tim Robins etc.. The story of a hot-shot American banker Andrew Dufresne(Tim Robins) who finds himself to be an inmate at the Shawshank prison for a crime he says he didn't commit, the murder of his wife and her lover. The movie revolves around Andy's take on this drastic transformation, his journey as an inmate in the prison during which he befriends Red(Morgan Freeman, a fellow inmate as well as gains the respect of his friends. The movie was actually adapted from a Novel by Stephen King named ***Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption. *** The movie wasn’t very successful in the box office but still was critically acclaimed and was loved by the audience. I would recommend anyone to watch this movie if they still haven’t. “Hope is a good thing, maybe the best of things, and no good thing ever dies.” - Andy Dufersne As stated in the quote this movie teaches a lot about Hope and how it drives a human to do insane things in his/her life.There are lots to take away from this movie and it is inspirational.

Here is a little, non-exhaustive list of some that truly made me think :  1. Memento. This one makes you think because it is purposefully a puzzle, which you will need to assemble yourself so to make sense of the overall story. Perfectly dizzying. 2. Interstellar. I am conscious that this movie has flaws and is often a little over-the-top in its plot, but I absolutely could not stop thinking about it after first viewing. The visuals and the idea are simply breathtaking and can really make you brain freeze. Beware the existential crisis. 3. Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind. A love story with a heavy sci-fi thread which will both make you think critically and make you reach for the Kleenex. 4. The Truman Show. A man with a seemingly perfect life slowly realizes that his entire existence is being watched by millions of strangers everyday. This one will make you think about how terrifying reality TV is, but it will also make you think about society itself. 5. American Psycho. The ultimate psychological thriller. It satires our society by showing an amplified version of the behavior so many of us adopt in order to fit in.

Life Is Beautiful Life Is Beautiful is a 1997 film about an Italian Jew - Guido - who helps his son survive the Holocaust by pretending it is all a game. When an open-minded Jewish librarian and his son become victims of the Holocaust, he uses a perfect mixture of will, humor and imagination to protect his son from the dangers around their camp.  Here are some conversations from movie Guido: (learning how to be a waiter) How far do I bow? I suppose I can even go 180 degrees. Eliseo: Think of a sunflower, they bow to the sun. But if you see some that are bowed too far down, it means they're dead. You're here serving, you're not a servant. Serving is the supreme art. God is the first of servants. God serves men, but he's not a servant to men.  Joshua: "No Jews or Dogs Allowed." Why do all the shops say, "No Jews Allowed"? Guido: Oh, that. "Not Allowed" signs are the latest trend! …The other day, I was in a shop with my Chinese friend and his pet kangaroo, but their sign said, "No Chinese or Kangaroos Allowed," and I said to my friend, "Well, what can I do? They don't allow kangaroos."  Guido: The game starts now. You have to score one thousand points. If you do that, you take home a tank with a big gun. Each day we will announce the scores from that loudspeaker. The one who has the fewest points will have to wear a sign that says "Jackass" on his back. There are three ways to lose points. One, turning into a big crybaby. Two, telling us you want to see your mommy. Three, saying you're hungry and want something to eat.

Let me give you two for the price of one real quick;  Godfather I & II are a must watch. It's got drama, mystery, suspense and best of all, some of the most brilliant acting you'll ever see. The direction is perfect, storyline has history and depth- I've yet to encounter a script so rich.  Now, 12 Angry Men, Shawshank Redemption and Citizen Kane are arguably some of the top rated movies ever released, but I'll have to go with 2001: A Space Odyssey (1968) by Kubrick just for the sheer beauty of it. Movie so ahead of its time, it spawned countless rumors and conspiracies about the actual moon landing. After all, no one has ever seen such gorgeous and flawless special effects before. Star Wars wouldn't be out for nearly another decade. This movie made all those awesome CGI movies of today, possible. It showed that creativity had no barrier.

People have different favorite genres. The definition of a good movie can differ from a person to another. This is something I noticed as a member of a huge family. However, there are occasions where my family and I agree that such film is a great one. And that’s my criteria on whether a movie is (should be) successful or not. Here I present you some of the movies that my family and I are fond of: -Bird box (2018): I can’t emphasize how good this movie is. I watched it many times, and every time I am astonished by the hidden hints and meanings. -Titanic (1997): This movie is an icon indeed. Although it received many criticism, it survived the test of time. After a good 20 years, many people are still watching this movie. I first watched it when I was 8 years old (a family-friendly version) and I still rewatch it from time to time. -The hunger games (2012): It might not be as good as the book, but it matched my expectations. -Circle (2015): One word to describe this movie: underrated. It is available on Netflix, yet only few people know about it. I loved how they made a good movie from a single scene. If you are interested in the philosophy of ethics, you are going to like this movie as it is a wider illustration of the trolly problem. -Fractured (2019): A huge plot twist. As I am a huge fan of plot twists, I enjoyed the great ending a lot. You will too. -If only (2004): Another movie with a good twist. A romantic one if you are fond of those. I hope this brings some help to you in picking a movie.

I'd say Shawshank Redemption. A period-prison drama based on a novella by Stephen King. The movie sends the most universal message a movie can send. It is the movie about hope. *Spoilers* It also tackles the theme of crime and punishment and the questions of injustice, innocence and true friendship. All the things that humans can understand and relate to, no matter whether they live in Austria, New Zealand, China, Botswana or any other country in the world. The two main actors were brilliant in their roles.  Tim Robbins played Andy, a good-hearted, honest and law-abiding banker who was wrongly accused of a double murder. Morgan Freeman played Red, Andy's loyal friend and the man who pushed him to fight and to continue to have faith, in spite of all the bad things that had happened to him. Red and Andy were a mighty duo. They were trying to make one another's life as easy as possible while living in prison for many years. Finding a bottle of beer or a poster of your favorite actress are some of the things that good friends do. The movie is awesome because it succeeded in evoking our emotions. It made us care for the inmates because they were portrayed as ordinary human beings (well, except for the vicious gang members). We didn't know much about their past, but we did care about what would happen to them in the future. Everyone could probably feel sadness after Andy had beaten and molested for no reason. The audience could also feel Andy's frustration. The surpressed and silent frustration after he was sent to the infamous prison for the crime he hadn't commited and the frustration mixed with disgust after the prison warden made everything in his power to keep Andy in prison indefinitely. I'm sure that all the people who watched the movie couldn't wait for the moment when Andy and Red would get out of there. People cared for them… Another reason for the movie's success is that the narrator telling the events was one and only - Morgan Freeman. The actor with one of the most recognizable and iconic voices ever. Red's rhytmical and soothing narration created the calming and very positive effect on the viewers. To cut the story short, I love this movie. I love the simplicity of the story and the array of emotions that the movie activates. Thanks for the A2A. For some interesting facts about the movie you can check these sites: 15 Things You Might Not Know About The Shawshank Redemption Ever Wondered Why 'The Shawshank Redemption' Is The Highest Rated Film On IMDb? I’ll give five suggestions that give a bit of an overview of cinema history. Yeah, that’s a little presumptuous but please indulge me. “The General” (1927) directed (and starring) Buster Keaton. One of the great silent films and fairly accessible to modern audiences. For students of film it showcases how a story is told purely visually.  “Citizen Kane” (1941) directed by Orson Welles. Though many of its game-changing aspects are now just part of filmmaking, Welles’ film is arguably the most influential piece of cinema in movie history. The following clip gives us an entire marriage in a few minutes.  “Seven Samurai” (1954) directed by Akira Kurosawa. A story about a small farming village takes on epic proportions and delivers sweeping battle scenes, yet maintains a delicate human intimacy. Simply essential.  “The Godfather” (1972) directed by Francis Ford Coppola. The mob meets Shakespearean tragedy and it works. It’s deliberately paced but patience yields rich rewards.  “No Country for Old Men” (2007) by The Coen Brothers. A potent examination of the nature and consistency of evil. Is it simply part of the human condition, or is it more insidious than that? Can one be evil yet have a code of sorts? Is humanity getting more evil as time goes on? Is violent death as random as the flip of a coin? These are just a few of the questions this remarkable film, based on the Cormac McCarthy novel, puts forward.

Well for 3 must see movies are:  The Shawshank Redemption (1994) - A story showing how your hope and outlook in life is what shapes your life experience, regardless of where you may be.  The Pursuit of Happyness (2006) - The Pursuit of Happynessis about a salesman (Will Smith) who undergoes defeats, challenges and hardship such as his wife leaving him, being rendered homeless, etc. to secure a better living for his son. Throughout his journey, he never once gave up, and stood firm to his goals. The mood of the show is slow and somber,intended for the audience to experience more fully what the character is going through. Besides determination, self-belief, persistence and going after ourdreams, the story also speaks strongly of a dad’s love for his child.  Rang De Basanti - The film revolves around a group of five friends who go through an entire roller coaster ride of changes. The changes aren't the ones youngsters usually encounter - these are changes that are very concrete and change their lives completely.

My Way  Simply put, this is the most epic war movie you will ever see. It follows the story of a Japanese war commander and a Korean soldier serving the Imperial Japanese army during WWII as they serve different sides of the war. Their innitial hatred turns into a brotherly friendship as the horrors of war sew their bonds for survival. Purely epic, and mere words cannot describe the awesomness that ensues. Wikipedias summary: This film is inspired by the true story of a Korean named Yang Kyoungjong who was captured by the Americans on D-Day. Yang Kyoungjong was conscripted into the Japanese Imperial Army, the Red Army, and the Wehrmacht. IMDb reviews:  Even if you are not a war movie fan, please for the love of god, watch this movie. YOU WILL NOT REGRET

“What's one movie you feel everyone should see?” The Postman is a 1997 American epic post-apocalyptic adventure. The film follows the story of a nomadic drifter (Kevin Costner) who travels through many of the surviving little villages, performing Shakespeare. The country is being terrorized by a totalitarian Hitler-like dictator, a former copier machine salesman. The drifter (Costner) stumbles across the uniform of a long gone United States Postal Service mail carrier, and unwittingly inspires hope through an empty promise of a "Restored United States of America" based on the presumed return of the postal service. Personally, I’ve always told my friends how The Postman was a wake up call. The same goes for Waterworld, also directed by Kevin Costner. Two little gems lost in time.

Must see for what? Light hearted romance? Action adventure? Drama? I think for romance, “Moonstruck” is a tour-de-force of writing. I think for action “Running Scared 2006” is the best movie I have ever seen. I think for drama “Michael Clayton” is the most under-rated movie out there. I think for sci-fi horror John Carpenter’s “The Thing” made in 1982 is still head and shoulders above everything out there I think for sheer entertainment “LA Confidential” is the best movie around I think for tear-jerking drama “Ordinary People” is one of the best movies ever made I think for war drama “Apocalypse Now” cannot be beat I think for straight comedy “Airplane” is the funniest movie ever made I think for the thinking man’s sci-fi “Blade Runner” is un-missable I think for simple, straight entertainment “Casablanca” may be the best movie ever made What does “Must See” mean to you?

Schindler's List (1993)  Director: Steven Spielberg Screenplay: Steven Zaillian Cast : Liam Neeson, Ralph Fiennes, Ben Kingsley Plot Steven Spielberg's Schindler's List revolves around a true story starring Liam Neeson as Oskar Schindler, a German businessman in Poland who sees an opportunity to make money from the Nazis' rise to power. He starts a company to make cookware and utensils, using flattery and bribes to win military contracts. He hires an accountant and financier Itzhak Stern (Ben Kingsley) to help run the factory. By staffing his plant with Jews. This all comes to turn when in 1942 all of Krakow's Jews are assigned to the Plaszow Forced Labor Camp, overseen by Commandant Amon Goeth. Schindler arranges to continue using Polish Jews in his plant, but, as he sees what is happening to his employees, he begins to develop a conscience. He realizes that his refitted ammunition factory is the only thing to help his staff from being shipped to the death camps. Soon Schindler demands more workers and starts bribing Nazi leaders to keep Jews on his employee lists and out of the camps. Soon after Germany’s defeat, Schindler has lost his entire fortune but had saved 1,100 people from likely death. Hope helped you with your answer

I think the real sign of a great movie is how it worms its way into your mind long after you’ve seen it and that’s the basis for these choices: Oldboy, the original not the confused and forgettable Spike Lee remake. Grabs your attention right from the opening scene and injects a real sense of peril as you don’t know what’s gonna to happen at any point. This confusion synchronizes perfectly with the story of an abducted man trying to find out why he was taken. A strange, disturbing and genuinely unforgettable film.  I Saw The Devil, starring the same lead actor as above and a great, if utterly disturbing, companion piece concerning a vengeance seeking lawman and a deranged killer. Tonally the film shifts gear multiple times, sometimes within the same scene; from stark violent bloodletting to laugh-out-loud humour and brio. Where these shifts may have broken any other film, here it’s perfectly in-keeping and even the bits that don’t quite work feel right somehow to the whole effect. Warning though, not for the faint of heart.  Pulp Fiction, Tarrantino at the height of his powers, marrying uber-cool dialogue with violent outbursts, dazzling camera work and a real love of the French New Wave and pulp story telling. Virtually every scene plays out like a director’s greatest hits and embeds itself on your memory, and the freshness is still evident. A film where everything clicks into place, the story flitting backwards and forwards in time to give a layered satisfaction to the whole.  Funny Games, pretty much any movie by Michael Haneke is memorable but his later remake of his own film with Tim Roth, Naomi Watts and Michael Pitt is one of his best. The plot is paper thin, a family taken hostage, but this is all part of this merciless satire on screen violence and audience complicity (great in context to the previous offerings!). The acting is superb, especially from Pitt who is mesmeric throughout and just when you think you know what’s happening Haneke pulls up sharply and does a u-turn or rewind. The timings are perfectly judged, just as you settle into an admittedly queasy horror film, he throws a reminder that all is not what it appears to be. Far from a dry treatise on cinematic violence, it’s fresh, unsettling and full of dry wit.  The Secret In Their Eyes based on a real period of Argentine history this beautifully acted thriller grabs your attention from the very first disappearance. Leaner and more quietly emotive than the Hollywood remake it stays with you long after watching and is a scary insight into a part of recent history.

response.answer_text: Well, you asked for a movie, so I’ll give you one. I could say Casablanca or Rear Window or The Godfather or Seven Samurai or Star Wars or Citizen Kane, but those are all incredibly obvious. (And in fact those are the six movies I named in Eric M. Van's answer to I am a beginner about movies. How should I start? Which movies should I watch?.) So, how about a movie that: Defines its genreMost people have heard of but …Many people have never seen because …Many people believe it’s so serious that watching it amounts to a sort of homework assignment, when in fact …It’s tremendously entertaining.And that film is Ingmar Bergman’s classic The Seventh Seal. Yes, it’s about a knight who is visited by Death and challenges him to a game of chess.  And yes, that plot thread is full of philosophical conversations about God that are so full of ideas I didn’t fully grasp them the until my third viewing. However, it is also full of sardonic humor, courtesy of the knight’s squire. Double however, it is also about a trio of traveling actors, including a radiantly beautiful Bibi Andersson, and this half of the story is lustful and comic.  Needless to say, every aspect of the filmmaking is extraordinary. It defines the genre of foreign arthouse films, but unlike many later entries in the genre, there’s always plenty happening. It is above all a film about Life, even more than it’s about Death and God.

Everyone? Maybe I’m taking your question too seriously, but I don’t think I’ve seen a fictional film that I think everyone should see. There are plenty of wonderful, moving, thoughtful, insightful films that I believe say something about the human condition or certain behaviours and that are valuable and sometimes even it is possible to learn something from. But I also know lots of people don’t appreciate that kind of cinema, or find reading subtitles distracting or a chore, or would consider it time wasted. Some of them are close friends, and I don’t consider them lesser people for that, though perhaps I might have when I was younger. One guy in particular could have written much the same piece, more or less, thinking about one of the new Avengers films or maybe Avatar (perhaps not Avatar…) or I don’t know what, raving about how it is simply great cinema and an experience everyone should partake of. I wouldn’t discount his opinion completely, but I know from conversation that we just have very different taste in films. Perhaps if there were more hours in the day… :) I seriously doubt anything is for everyone, and long may that continue.

1 - La vita è bella (Life is Beautiful) (1997) (Comedy, Drama, Romance) When an open-minded Jewish librarian and his son become victims of the Holocaust, he uses a perfect mixture of will, humor, and imagination to protect his son from the dangers around their camp.  2 - Schindler’s List (1993) (Biography, Drama, History) In German-occupied Poland during World War II, Oskar Schindler gradually becomes concerned for his Jewish workforce after witnessing their persecution by the Nazi Germans.  3 - Intouchables (2011) (Biography, Comedy, Drama) After he becomes a quadriplegic from a paragliding accident, an aristocrat hires a young man from the projects to be his caregiver.  4 - Shawshank Redemption (1994) (Drama) Two imprisoned men bond over a number of years, finding solace and eventual redemption through acts of common decency.  5 - A Beautiful Mind (2001) (Biography, Drama) After John Nash, a brilliant but asocial mathematician, accepts secret work in cryptography, his life takes a turn for the nightmarish.

I really enjoyed The Butler (2013)The Butler (full title Lee Daniels' The Butler)[4][5] is a 2013 American historical drama film directed and produced by Lee Daniels and written by Danny Strong.[6] Loosely based on the real life of Eugene Allen, the film stars Forest Whitaker as Cecil Gaines, an African-American who is a witness of notable political and social events of the 20th century during his 34-year tenure serving as a White House butler.[7][8] In addition to Whitaker, the film's all-star cast also features Oprah Winfrey, John Cusack, Jane Fonda, Alex Pettyfer, Cuba Gooding, Jr., Terrence Howard, Lenny Kravitz, James Marsden, David Oyelowo, Vanessa Redgrave, Alan Rickman, Liev Schreiber, Robin Williams, Mariah Carey and Clarence Williams III. It was the last film produced by Laura Ziskin,[9][10] who died in 2011. Wikipedia

M (1931). It’s more than your run-of-the-mill whodunnit tale, it’s also an exploration on the plurality of good and evil — how even the police can be unjust, and how criminals can be righteous. It sheds some light on the integrity of law as a profession, and how defense of what is perceived as ‘wrong’ still merits a fair trial in an impartial court. More importantly, it reminds us that despite the effort we put in the improvement of the criminal justice system, true reparations can never happen. It’s a somber ending, but one that reflects real life. I also loved the attention to small detail — how only a blind man can offer any real information on the culprit’s identity; and how the shot stayed a beat too long on an empty table when the children are missing.

#1 The Pursuit of Happyness The Pursuit of Happyness is based on the true story of Chris Gardener and his son Christopher. It shows the hardships faced by Chris (played by Will Smith) and Christopher (played by Jaden Smith) as they try to survive in the daily world. Powered by a terrific performance by Will Smith, this movie gives us an inspiring and a heart-touching story that’ll make most of the audience emotional. #2 Shawshank Redemption Shawshank Redemption has stood the test of time and still stands tall. This movie tops the list of the best movies on IMDb. Starring Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman, The Shawshank Redemption was based on the book by Stephen King. The movie mentions the importance of not losing hope in one’s life, no matter what the situation might be. #3 The Godfather Perhaps the most influential movie of all time. Directed by Francis Ford Coppola, the movie has inspired a generation of filmmaking. The Godfather is a neo-noir film that showcases the gang wars between different mafia gangs in America. A true testament to art cinema, Godfather also has extraordinary performances by Al Pacino, Marlon Brando, and Robert de Niro. #4 Fight Club Fight Club is a movie that released in 1999 and was directed by David Fincher. It’s a cult movie that has been tagged as one of the manliest movies of all time. It stars Edward Norton and Brad Pitt and has many rebellious concepts. The movie is thought-provoking and has one of the most amazing twists at the end. You just cannot miss this movie and is one of the must-watch Hollywood movies. #5 Inception Inception is a movie that marveled both the audiences and the critics alike. It involves concepts of dreams and limbo that require high skills to be portrayed on the screen Christopher Nolan amazed one and well with the way in which he managed to pull off such a complex storyline. Leonardo DiCaprio, Tom Hardy, Ellen Page, and Joseph Gorden-Levit delivered superb performances to back this brilliant script #6 Schindler’s List Directed by Steven Spielberg, Schindler’s List released in 1993. It shows the true story of Oskar Schindler who had managed to save many Jews from the atrocities of the Nazis during the second world war. It won the Academy award for the best picture in 1993 and is a proof to what a movie can achieve. Realistic, powerful, and hard-hitting, Schindler’s list is perhaps the best war movie that has ever been made. #7 Interstellar In a recent poll held by a famous website, Interstellar was voted as the most favourite movie of the 21st century. Interstellar stands as a true testament to Christopher Nolan’s vision directorial brilliance. Interstellar is a sci-fi movie that deals with concepts such as black holes and life and on other planets. Starring Matthew McConaughey, Anne Hathaway, and Matt Damon, Interstellar is a spectacle that no film lover can afford to miss. #8 The Dark Knight Trilogy The trilogy that revamped the Batman franchise. The trilogy consists of Batman Begins(2005), The Dark Knight (2008), and the Dark Knight Rises (2012). Christian Bale dons the Batman avatar in all these films. This trilogy, especially the Dark Knight, stands out of other Superhero movies with its plot and storytelling. Special mention to Heath Ledger who absolutely nailed the Joker’s role in the second installment of the series. #9 12 Angry Men This 1957 classic is counted as one of the greatest films of all time. Not only is this movie used to teach lessons in filmmaking, but is also used in training MNC corporates. 12 Angry Men is a court room drama that involves an intense and a logical plot. The entire movie was shot in a single room and underlines the power of one’s persuasion skills and conviction #10 The Prestige This movie which released in 2006, will keep you glued to your seats right until its very end. Directed by Christopher Nolan, Prestige stars Hugh Jackman and Christian Bale as two rival magicians who try to outsmart each other. It’s an intriguing tale of deceit and drama as both the protagonists run after fame at the cost of some dire consequences. Nolan manages to keep the audience hooked with his brilliant way of storytelling.

I don’t think it’s a fair question. Avatar may be the current cinematic champ, but that’s based on current currency valuations, not on butts-in-seats. One of the biggest movies of this past year was the Asian film “The Mermaid”, but that hardly got a quality U.S. release. Not everybody is into Star Wars or comic book films, and not everybody has children. And if you look at past cinematic champions, movies such as “Birth of a Nation” and “Gone With The Wind” are among the most popular, but are greatly ignored by the current generation due to racial concerns (justified in the former, not in the latter). Face it, we are a divided nation, a divided world. We have no common culture; no common worldview, no common language. There are a couple of films that I think a LOT of people should have seen by now (Star Wars, Toy Story, and A Christmas Story), but no film that I would suspect everybody has seen.

Before getting in to the plot, first I wish to narrate about our family details. We are a Tamil family and none of us speak or understand Hindi. At least I can speak little bit of business Hindi (surely cannot understand a movie) but my family members are almost zero. We hardly watch Hindi movies. In my childhood days my parents took me to the movie Qurbani and all I can remember until now from the movie is the song “Aap Jaisa koyi” and nothing else. After I grown up I watched only Hum Aapke Hai Kaun, Gupt, Dil toh pagal hai and Kuch Kuch Hota Hai since all these are musical blockbusters across India irrespective of the language. I not even watched the best of the famous movies like Qayamat se Qayamat tak and Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge. These movies where running successfully for more than 100 days in my city at Coimbatore, which is a big achievement in a Tamil Speaking city. I watched movies like Munnabhai MBBS, Jolly LLB in the remade Tamil version. Now coming to the point I think the best movie I watched after all these is KAL HO NAA HO  Image Credit: Google & Dharma Productions This happened around 10 to 12 years back. I don’t properly remember how I got the CD of KHNH. I think one of our neighbors gave it. Somehow I and my family started watching the CD in our house. Even there were no English subtitles in it. First nobody were much interested in the movie. Then the location caught our attention and then the excellent cinematography. Though we couldn’t understand much of the Dialogues, we were slowly lured in to the film bcoz of the excellent acting of SRK, Saif, Preity and all others. And finally in the Climax scene all of us where crying visibly. I think that is the success of this movie. Though we cannot understand the dialogues, not understood much about the story in detail but at the end we couldn’t stop the tears… Awesome!! For the next few years my phone’s ring tone was “It’s the time to Disco”. Until today I tried watching it again with English Subtitles. But not yet… Now it is available in Amazon Prime Videos. Sooner or later I will watch it again.. Also one of my friends suggested watching the Akshay Kumar, Paresh Rawal starer “OMG - Oh My God”. Yet to watch it!

I tried to stay away from some main-stream modern movies here and I am always looking for good movies. The internet usually spits out the Godfather and Shawshank Redemption, obviously master classes in film making, but it is always great to stumble on movies that you may not have heard of, and finding out they are entertaining. These are some good movies I have stumbled across, a couple of indie films and reaching into the back catalogue.  Boogie Nights - Movies are best when they are entertaining, tense, and filled with humor. This movie has all three. The final scene is one of the most nerve-wracking things I have ever watched. The film also has a great cast including: Mark Whalberg, Burt Reynolds, and John C. Reilly, among others. 2. Leave No Trace - A more indie film, and a heart-breaker. I usually don’t go for the indie drama movies, but this one is great. If it doesn’t pull on your heartstrings you probably don’t have any.  3. Upgrade - A quirky sci-fi adventure. A decent watch with unique camera work that adds a whole other level to the movie.  4. True Romance - An early Tarantino work and you can definitely feel his hand at work. While most films have one climax this movie seems to have three or four riveting scenes. There is some iconic dialogue and the film drips with tension.  5. Prisoners - An underrated movie with deep and interesting themes. It makes you wonder what you would do in the same situation? To what lengths would you go to protect your family?

The following movies certainly are thoughtful enough to make the list in answer to your question. In various ways, these films address the human condition and engage the viewer to reflect on life. I further suggest these movies are required viewing for any serious screenwriters. Both the films and the screenplays are worthy of study. “The Paper” written by David & Steven Koepp “Schindler’s List” written by Steven Zaillian “Dead Poets Society” written by Tom Schulman “Searching for Bobby Fischer” written and directed by Steven Zaillian “Network” written by Paddy Chayefsky “Avalon” written by Barry Levinson “The Shawshank Redemption” written and directed by Frank Darabont “Gandi” written by John Briley “The Da Vinci Code” written by Akiva Goldsman “Wall Street” written by Oliver Stone and Stanley Weiser “Field of Dreams” written by Phil Alden Robinson “V for Vendetta” written by the Wachowski Brothers “Broadcast News” written and directed by James L. Brooks “My Life” written by Bruce Joel Rubin “Ghost” written by Bruce Joel Rubin “Dances with Wolves” written by Michael Blake This is hardly a complete list. I would appreciate reading other replies to this interesting question. Also, I am curious if anyone has a favorite among the films I listed above.

The Machinist – In my opinion this movie is one of the finest movies of Christian Bale’s career.  We know Bale is a method actor, but for the movie Bale lost 62 pounds! The dedication of Bale makes it a must-watch movie. Although this movie is a bit depressing, it can leave you low in spirit. It’s not for the faint hearted people. Interstellar –  Science, Cosmology, Worm Holes on the big screen, nobody could have presented it in a better way except Nolan. The movie is about a crew of astronauts who travel through a wormhole in space in search of a new home, to survive. Like most of the Nolan movies you’ll need brains in your head to watch it. Love is the one thing that transcends time and space. Fight Club –  Over the time Fight Club has become a cult hit, based on the novel of the same name by Chuck Palahniuk. This movie has some deep philosophy and it questions our lifestyle as consumers. Different people have different interpretations of the movie. Starring Brad Pitt, Edward Norton, directed by David Fincher, this movie is a must see. This is all time favorite movie of all the mindfuck movies.

There is this movie in English which I watched and found really interesting : 1)The Imitation Game  This is a story of world famous mathematician– Alan Turin(Benedict Cumberbatch). It depicts his journey during World War II, when the English mathematician Apan Turing tries to crack the German Enigma code with help from fellow mathematicians. The machine he created to break the code came to be known as Turing Machine. The film switches between the drive of the team of code breakers to solve the Enigma code, young Alan Turing and the events after the war that destroyed his life. It is truly heartbreaking in places, and Benedict Cumberbatch's performance, as Alan Turing is outstanding as always. It has been a long time I enjoyed a movie so much. I will not give any spoilers about the movie, as it is a movie which is worth watching!!!!! BLOOD DIAMOND  One of the most underrated movies of Leonardo DiCaprio. This movie is an attempt to make people realize the situation in West Africa (Sierra Leone) and how conflict diamonds are being transported/smuggled. What are conflict diamonds you ask ? Conflict Diamonds are diamonds illegally traded to fund conflict in war-torn areas, particularly in central and western Africa. The United Nations (UN) defines conflict diamonds as "...diamonds that originate from areas controlled by forces or factions opposed to legitimate and internationally recognized governments, and are used to fund military action in opposition to those governments, or in contravention of the decisions of the Security Council." These diamonds are sometimes referred to as "blood diamonds." The movie does not shy away from depicting violence or the horrors of war !  Source: Google Images

I will mention some movies which make you think twice about your life, your goals and the reality you are living in. Fight Club“We buy things we don’t need with money we don’t have to impress people we don’t like” Rocky It tells the rags to riches American Dream story of Rocky Balboa, an uneducated but kind-hearted working class Italian-American boxer working as a debt collector for a loan shark in the slums of Philadelphia. I have some classic movies which will probably blow your mind away. Groundhog Day This is like the masterpiece of masterpieces. Many may have watched it but still, I don’t think our young generation knows about it. Groundhog day involves the story of a man who lives the same day over and over again, without any consequences thereafter. Not many know this but some of our modern day blockbusters such as Happy Death Day, Baar Baar Dekho, and Edge of Tomorrow have copied this film’s concept. Indeed a beautiful movie.Sixth Sense This movie has arguably the greatest plot twist of all time. Even without the twist, it is suitable enough to give you chills. A child who can see dead people is helped by a psychologist. It is an all time horror classic.3. Jallikattu  This film is a rare Indian gem. It’s cinematography is amazing, and its concept is brand new. At some points one can even compare the directing to Nolan’s. A brilliant underrated move which is available on Amazon Prime Video. (PS. IT’S NOT BOLLYWOOD) 4. Karthik Calling Karthik  Perhaps the only Bollywood movie that stuck with me, Karthik Calling Karthik is a psychological thriller which deals with a man receiving calls from himself. It is a great watch. 5. The Big Lebowski  This is a movie which actually inspired an ENTIRE RELIGION. It has great detail for character, has unending twists and till the end moment, you’ll never be able to figure out what ‘s going on and you’ll still enjoy it. It’s a comedy for a lifetime. Some of these are available on streaming sites, some of these you’ll have to download, but hey, they’re worth it. If you want to enjoy your quarantine to the fullest, I got these five movies for you.

Okay, this is subjective. There are a lot of movies out there. But if I had to choose 3 that you must see, it's these: The Lion King (1994)  a movie ultimately about loss and how we cope on our own: Lion King is incredibly heartbreaking, as it illustrates the struggle of facing the world on your own.  Rocky (1976)  Persistence is key. That’s what Rocky taught me: if you want something, you're going to have to work for it - harder and harder each day. Rocky fought for what he wanted, overcoming the odds. There's such a valuable lesson to be learned from this movie.  The Way Way back (2013)  The way way back is a really fun movie, and it taught me that, 1. Steve Carell is a talented actor; 2. Being yourself is okay. You should always value yourself even if others don't. You're worth more than they say. :)  These movies are must see, to me, simply because they teach us wonderful things.

I highly recommend everyone to watch ‘Slumdog Millionaire’.  I do believe it encompasses a lot of topics of life. It speaks from experience, it speaks of tragedy, speaks of love, speaks of family, speaks of knowledge, speaks of politics, speaks of corruption, speaks of money, and finally, portrays happiness in its completeness. I found this movie to have captured my full attention as the movie challenged me to think about my own experiences, and how they shaped me up to be the person I am. I never took any experience, happy or sad, for granted. Each experience does teach you a valuable lesson, and although it may not seem important or seem minuscule, you’ll someday think back and realize it changed your life for the better, or for worse; something you can definitely learn from. It’s an all-around beautiful movie, and no other movie can teach you so many life lessons.

We’re the Millers! If you’re a fan of romcom movies (which I am), this movie is the perfect solution for you. I have loved romcom movie genre for all my life and this one is the most hilarious one I’ve ever watched. This one is not quite romantic, I suppose, it is more of pure comedy and slightly romantic at the end. Another one that I might recommend is probably The Switch. Both of these movies are all Jennifer Aniston’s, which I’m supposed I’m a fan of, and they’re both amazing and well-deserved to be remembered. I’ve seen them a couple of times now and never get bored of them. I would find myself wanting to see those movies again and again from time to time since they are really cool and memorable ;D Almost all of Adam Sandler’s movies are all also awesome and hilarious. Never get bored or tired of every single one of them either. Especially Grown Ups 1&2 and Just Go With It (starring Jen again :)))

Quite recently, I watched a movie called THE GREEN MILE .It had full worth over my time and this 3 hour long movie won't make you settle down relaxed.  Reasons why this will be a perfect entertainer: TOM HANKS has carried out an extraordinary performance and has full dominance over his role. This movie portrays the characters of three prison officers who are in charge of the death sentenced captives. Each convict is different and the way TOM HANKS handles them is almost impeccable.  JOHN COFFEY is the name of the other prisoner and his acting skills is almost the backbone of this movie. There are also a few breathtaking scenes happening in between the story. My Answer assumes that you are on your journey of becoming a “Cinephile”. Answer : Schindler’s List (1993)  Paraphrasing "I could've done more" has to be one of the most heartbreaking lines of dialogue in not only this movie, but any movie. It sums up the world's feelings and regrets for not having done more. It is a regret that we will always live with, voiced very eloquently by Neeson. By far Spielberg's most powerful film and shows truly what a master of his craft he truly is. The black and white felt like all that old concentration camp footage we have seen over the years giving it that realism that made it even more uncomfortable to watch. Fiennes performance was dynamic from monster to person to monster. It makes us wonder how people can become this way. Are they truly evil or not even realize that they are evil. Or is that this biggest form of absolute evil? The film's running length seems to breeze by, although every moment feels completely heavy. I cannot think of another film that has ever had such an effect. This is something that should be shown in every school as a mandatory requirement. May we never forget this precious and essential work of art.

I have to admit to liking the science fiction genre very much. Of course, it does not appeal to everyone, but to those that it does appeal to, there's a very good chance that the source of that appeal is the concept of "Is this possible?". A lot of the movies have been "re-done" in different forms and settings, so may it is better to describe the concepts, rather than specific movies. Human cloning.   In The Island (2005), the concept if human cloning is explored.  What if you could add 50 or 60 years for your life?  Would you?   For the ultra rich in this movie the answer was yes.  Clones were "grown" for the purposes of replacement organs for their "hosts."  Liver, lung cancer or bad car accident?  No problem, we'll get replacements for your failing organs from your clone -- an identical biological match.  Although they were told that the clone was a "product" and never achieved consciousness, that turned out be a lie, as the organs failed without any type of human interaction.  Ethical considerations aside, the idea is pretty intriguing. Time Travel.  Even though it doesn't seem possible, what if it were?  Discussing time paradoxes can drive one to the brink of insanity. The time paradox.   If you went back in time and murdered your grandfather before he had kids, how could you have gone back in time to murder him?   Back To The Future (1985), Somewhere In Time (1980), Timecop (1994), Peggy Sue Got Married (1986) are just a few of the many time travel movies made.  I wouldn't be the least bit surprised if there were hundreds made throughout the decades.  An interesting topic without a doubt.  Admit it, you've thought about -- what if I could go back in time?...

Two of my 3 are old. : Number 1: A must watch is The best anti-war film ever is BLACK AND WHITE IN COLOUR, Set in WWI Africa it is a historically revealing story about French colonials vs. German colonials led by German officers clash with French colonials led by a retired French policeman and (spoiler alert) a scientist/academic. This film is interlaced with deep economic/nationalist/religious undercurrents. 2) The best single horror film (without blood or physicality) is the French “DIABOLIQUE”. A will provide a test of your ability to evaluate the 3 main characters and how the climax will be reached. Lot’s of spooky goings on before the shocking end that will have you spilling your popcorn and grabbing your seat mates armrest ( or arm). 3) “ANIMAL HOUSE”: I know you are asking yourself “really”? After dealing with War & horror why not a visit the absolutely mindless, sophomoric, sexist escapades of a frat-house filled with chronic underachievers? Must you watch it instead of “Birth of a Nation” ( rise of the KKK) or “Triumph of the Will” ( rise of Naizism) ? Probably not, but it’s a lot shorter than one of the versions of “War and Peace” or “Stalingrad” and not nearly as violent as “John Wick” ( 1 through 3). All three of my picks are available on-line and your home-popped snack is cheaper and tastier..

The Dark Knight. Reasons: The pacing is pretty much perfect. Every single scene is a turning point in the story. There is absolutely no dead weight.A villain that actually terrifies the audience. He is unpredictable and is delightful to watch in a weird psychopathic way.The theme is beautifully woven into the story. Every scene has a shade of the theme in it. This leads to an immersive quality of theme that is lacking in many movies (even Christopher Nolan’s own movies). Combining this with a great theme-extreme measures must be taken to preserve order because men aren’t as moral as they think they are-and you have a powerful movie.

Everyone is giving an Hollywood movie suggestion .but I am going to a Bollywood movie . DANGAL Dangal is biopic of mahavir phogat.  Mahavir belongs to Balali, a small village in Haryana, which did not give him his expected rights for raising his daughters. Mahavir’s wife’s name isDaya Kaur, who has equally supported him in achieving his dreams and goals. His love for his daughters does not reflect in his words, but in his actions. He quit his job to raise and coach his little angels, so that they can turn toinspiring personalities. Today, more than a wrestler, Mahavir is famous for his coaching skills and the support that reflects through his daughters. Things were not as easy as it seems. Mahavir has gone through a roller coaster ride to explain people why it is important to raise your daughters equally instead of pushing them to marry. He has defied many arguments, risked his own life and career; despite the hurdles, he stands alone to fight back the challenges posed for his daughters. When he began coaching his daughters, Mahavir did not know if he will be successful in creating an interest in his daughters` hearts for wrestling. It is only his passion and his daughters` love for him, which has together brought him this recognition.

The Shaw shank Redemption Hollywood Film of Year 1994 The Shawshank Redemption is a 1994 American drama film written and directed by Frank Darabont, and starring Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman. Adapted from the Stephen King novella Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption, the film tells the story of Andy Dufresne, a banker who is sentenced to life in Shaw shank State Penitentiary for the murder of his wife and her lover, despite his claims of innocence. During his time at the prison, he befriends a fellow inmate, Ellis Boyd "Red" Redding, and finds himself protected by the guards after the warden begins using him in his money-laundering operation.

Being kind of a sentimental fool, I would say Princess Bride is my best love story. I was, and still am, enamored with Robin Wright. A rocking suspenseful tome that has dystopian qualities. The first time Hitchcock went animal in one of his films. Journey to the Center of the Earth, 1959, staring Pat Boone, Arlene Dahl, James Mason and the big swede with Gertrude. Some great geological bits, mashed with a perilous adventure. Pat Boone sings, James Mason orates, Arlene Dahl looks high-society sexy, and the big swede and Gertrude round out the team. Beautiful music score. (Runner up): The Time Machine (old version), staring Rod Taylor again. An H.G. Wells masterpiece and first glimpse into the future. Warlocks = very frightening cannibals. The machine, beautifully crafted; the sets and environment very realistic. Great music score.

Polanski , 2019 : In 1894, French Captain Alfred Dreyfus is wrongfully convicted of treason and sentenced to life imprisonment at Devil's island.The Platform , 2019 : A vertical prison with one cell per level. Visaranai (tamil) Visaranai to take a shot at Oscar nomination  Thriller on police brutality chosen as official Indian entry to Best Foreign Language Film. Visaranai, the Tamil docu-drama crime thriller, has been chosen India’s official entry to Best Foreign Language Film category at the 89th Academy Awards to be held in 2017. The national award-winning film, directed by Vetrimaran, and produced by actor Dhanush’s Wunderbar Films, documents four migrant workers who suffer police brutality and corruption after being jailed on false charges. Part of the film is based on true events recorded in novel Lock Up, written by M. Chandrakumar, an autorickshaw driver from Coimbatore. Dhanush said it was a proud and joyous moment for his production house and director Vetrimaran. He praised the cast and crew of the film as ‘fantastic.’ The last Tamil movie that made it to the list as official entry to the Oscars was Hey Ram, directed by, and starring Kamal Haasan. The film was simultaneously made in Hindi in 2000. Mr. Vetrimaran told The Hindu that he was extremely happy and the news was a pleasant surprise. “The movie continues to be very relevant. We are now preparing for the next step, and hope the film will earn a nomination,” he said. The film’s chances will be known in January. Visaranai, starring Dinesh Ravi, Samuthirakani, Kishore, Ajay Ghosh, Anandhi and Aadukalam Murugadoss, premiered at the Venice International Film festival in 2015 and had a theatrical release in February 2016.

Taare Zameen Par  The protagonist of the movie is Ishan Avasthi, an 8 year old who suffers from dyslexia and hates studies and loves painting. It does not help that his elder brother is a genius. He keeps getting poor marks but he can't help it. His dad thinks Ishan is just being lazy so he sends him to a boarding school. There Ishan sinks into depression. His situation changes when a new art teacher joins the school. And then what happens? I can't explain that in words. Mind you, this movie is not about dyslexia or any disease. Its about how parents pressurise their children to be a topper in their class rather than helping them find their passion. This movie tells us that every child is special. It will make you cry and will probably change the way you think. Please watch it.

Most of my favourite movies have already been mentioned in other answers hence I'll write about a left out which I really liked TAXI DRIVER A Martin Scorsese classic  Story of the movie builds up slowly but confidently. It's one among those movies where viewer has no idea what protagonist is capable of At first we are introduced to a protagonist who is socially awkward, isolated.(anti-hero) He is not like us. He doesn't follow the same social norm life we follow. But still we hold up that he somehow save himself from the danger, We all symphatize. But as the film progresses it's apparent that he has some mental issues. he is not aggressive nor defensive he's just unaware. Audience will have no idea where the story is heading to. As the climax approaches his mental instability gives different feeling for the viewer. His actions are horrific, unsettling. What discomforts the most is he's actually been rewarded for those actions.  I have skipped most of the details as I don't want to ruin the experience of watching this movie for the first time. If you are looking for a movie you wanna dig into then it's a must watch.

Shawshank redemption( 1994)  The shawshank redemption is the one movie that you must watch. Highest rated movie on IMDB and adapted from stephen king’s novel Rita hayworth and shawshank redemption , this movie is about losing everything in life and then winning the one thing that matters most in life -’happiness’ The protagonist Andy dufresne(Tim robbbins) is convicted of murdering his wife and her lover and is sent to shawshank state penitentiary. Here he befriends ‘red’ (morgan freeman) who helps him to get a rita hayworth poster. The thing that makes Andy a special character is his ability to accept the good and the bad the same way. The movie progresses slowly and has its bits of life and humour in it and warmth of friendship. Their is suspense although not when one will expect it. The entire movie builds up to the glorious end -The redemption of Andy dufresne. As Andy himself puts it- Remember red ,hope is a good thing,maybe the best of things,and no good thing ever dies.

I mean no disrespect but this is truly a silly question. Movies belong to the arts. There are no universal standards by which to measure which movies are the best. Fortunately. There aren’t even any standards by which to determine what “best” means in this context. If you are looking for absolute standards, you should focus on sports, science or business. The richest man in the world is Bill Gates. How do we know this? - because he has a fortune of 86 Billion which is exactly 11.6 Billion more than Warren Buffet. The fastest runner is Usain Bolt. How do we know this? - Because he holds the world records in both the 100- and 200-meter dashes (9.58 and 19.19, respectively). But which flower is the prettiest? which dish is the best tasting? which politcal party is the best? which movie is the best? Give me a universal standard and I’ll tell you. But it will be the saddest day in human history, when and if these questions can ever be answered. Because that would mean that there is no longer room for individual taste. And individuality is what makes us who we are, So be happy that this question can never and should never be answered.

Watch Soylent Green because the eerie film is literally laden with darkly lurid subliminal messaging, for example, the corpses are wrapped in a color and shape which, when they’re flowing down the conveyor belt, makes them look much like Tylenol capsules. Soylent, from the film’s cryptic title, is an anagram for Tylenol. It’s true that rearranging the letters in Soylent you get Tylenos, yet the proof that it’s really Tylenol is that L is the twelfth letter of the alphabet and S is the nineteenth letter so that when you subtract 12 from 19 you get 7 which is exactly the number of letters in Soylent. There’s a scene in this mind-warping cult film where an announcer advertising Soylent Green says, “Tuesday is Soylent Green day.” There are seven letters in Tuesday, same as Soylent and Tylenol. Soybean has seven letters. Soy is supposed to be a reliable source of protein. The word protein contains seven letters. The founder of the company that would invent Tylenol, Robert McNeil, had a son who managed the company for fifty years. His son’s middle name was Lincoln. There are seven letters in the name Lincoln. Thinking of Soylent containing seven letters, we note that there are seven days in a week. Soylent Green combined has twelve letters. There are twelve months in a year. The film is designed to subliminally suggest Malthusian dystopia. Malthusian of course refers to the early 19th century economist, Malthus. In the name Malthus there are seven letters including the L and the S which are the connecting link between Soylent, Tylenos, and Tylenol.

There are two things people go crazy for in India. One is cricket and the other is movies. Just mix them together with a blend of drama, romance, and action, and you'll get a film that becomes favorite of every Indian. It was not so long ago that almost-unknown director Ashutosh Gowrikar teamed up with Aamir Khan (who not only played the lead role in the film but also co-produced it) to try their hand at the above formula. The setting was a small village in Gujrat, the era was of British India, and the subject was cricket. This set-up was enough to create a film that resonated with every Indian. No wonder the film was a super hit and popularized the trend of patriotic movies initiated by Gadar at that time. The film also gave Aamir the tag of 'Mr. Perfectionist.' Lagaan is that rare Hindi film that represented India in world cinema.

The Pursuit of Happyness.This movie was directed by Gabriele Muccino. It is based on the struggle of an entrepreneur being homeless. Will Smith is starred in this film as a homeless salesman. The financial instability ruins their married life, in spite of them caring for their five-year-old son.It ends, after telling the audience that Chris Gardner went on to own his own investment company and makes millions of dollars The song A Fathers’s Way is also from this movie.  Smith was nominated for an Academy Award and a Golden Globe for Best Actor for his performance in this film.

One movie which stuck with me after watching it years ago was The Reader (2008). A brief plot summary from Wikipedia: “It tells the story of Michael Berg, a German lawyer who, as a mid-teenager in 1958, has an affair with an older woman, Hanna Schmitz, who then disappears only to resurface years later as one of the defendants in a war crimes trial stemming from her actions as a guard at a Nazi concentration camp. Michael realizes that Hanna is keeping a personal secret she believes is worse than her Nazi past – a secret which, if revealed, could help her at the trial.” If you expect intense fight scenes or heavy set action sequences, you won’t find them here. It is a heartwrenching drama about love, and the way in which it survives in bizzare circumstances. Masterful performances by Winslet and Fiennes.

The Man from Earth (2007) It is one of the most under-appreciated movies of this century. It is a movie that was all shot in just one room. There are no elaborate effects, fight scenes or super popular actors, but instead, it is entirely focused on the story and the way the story is told. It is a one of a kind movie. The entire movie is about the conversation a professor has with his friends. But those discussions are so thought-provoking and engaging that you wouldn’t be able to stop yourself from finishing the movie even if it is 3 in the morning. It tackles some of the fundamental questions regarding human existence, religion and belief system.  I’m the kind of person that doesn’t usually have any favorites. Whether you ask me about my favorite actors, actresses, shows, I usually can’t tell you now answer. I would either won’t give any names or will give you a big list of all the names that I can think of. But Still, I can say without any hesitation that “The Man from earth” is my favorite movie and it will most likely stay that way for a very long time. This movie has made a deep impact on me. We need more movies like this to come and raise awareness and makes them think. If you have not watched this movie, stop reading this and do yourself a favor by watching that movie. I’m telling you, you would definitely love it. So, Go!

The movies mentioned are from the Malayalam Film Industry. A fact about the Malayalam Film Industry is that the movies are that they have a realistic approach to the direction rather than unlike the other Indian films (where a person takes a human heart and throws it into the Operation Theater, for his lover who is having a heart transplant). The 10 movies that got a lesson to make a meaningful life are as follows:- Neelakasham Pachakadal Chuvanna Bhoomi (2013) Kazi, an Engineering student from Calicut goes on a road-ride with Royal Enfield to Nagaland in order to meet his lover along with his companion, Suni from Kannur. It depicts the value of valueof love, friendship, family and that is why this is one of the marked films in history of Malayalam. This movie is also known as an inspiration for the youth Malayalee people to travel to the Northern Indian States with a bike. 2. Hey Jude (2018)  A true masterpiece from Nivin Pauly. An introverted nerd named Jude is always fascinated by the aquatic world and is always doing his study on it, seminars and other projects. He goes to Goa with family as his family think to make him a better person for the future. Meeting different people in Goa makes him a little bit extroverted and in the end he is seen as a successful Scientist. 3. Queen (2018)  Unrealistically, a girl named Chinnu joins for studying Mechanical Engineering in a College and she befriends most of the boys in the class. Her friends come to know that she was a suffering patient and she is raped to death in the movie. As always, the truth is discovered towards the end of the movie but the message from this movie is that, the society must understand that “A girl is not being a slut if she has a lot of male friends. It is her wish whom to befriend.” In today’s India society there is a misconception with this topic and this must be erased and I guess this movie is a good choice to show the public. 4. Aakashamittayi (2017)  This is one of the most meaningful movies I ever saw. Two families raise their only child in two different way. One father gives his child all the freedom, moral values, education, knowledge and the other father rauses his child with strict atmosphere and forces him to study and wants a Doctor out of him. Gradually the first guy becomes a successful and well maintained teenager while the other boy suicides because of pressure and forcing. Parents please do understand the skill of your child and raise them that way. Tomorrow they will be the Wings of Mercy like you all wanted. This is a request from an 18 year old. 5. Comrade in America (2017)  Aji Mathew meets an NRI girl from USA in his college at Kottayam and he falls in love with her. Later she is forced by her parents to move back to USA so that she gets away from the relationship. As she is back in US her family decides her marriage and in between she asks Aji Mathew to come to US all the way from India to convince her parents. As there is shortage of time to reach US, Aji Mathew plans to do the illegal way of entering USA via Mexican border and he does so enter and meets his cousin USA. Later he discovers from his cousin that his lover has changed the mind and she is getting ready for the marriage with her fiancee and meanwhile Aji’s father requests him to attend her marriage as a way of respect and revenge. The lesson is that always give value for the true love our partner gives. They are even ready to risk their life to make you happy. Never ever make it rotten, for you are the one who will be hit with Karma. 6. Jomonte Suvisheshangal (2017)  Vincent a successful businessman loses his properties following a pledging for loan, and Jomon, his son does all the hard work when other children who are successful ignores their father. Jomon earned a lot of money buy making business with small-scaled textile sellers in Tamil Nadu and finally buys back the lost house and he manages to bring together back the family all together. Lesson learnt is Hard work pays off. 7. Paipin Chuvattile Pranayam (2017)  Not that great movie but still there a lot of things to enjoy. This is a kind of media coverage movie that gives the message to the Government that there are people in remote places of Kerala that struggle for water, transport and other facilities. This is a simple movie and the movie scenes aren’t extravagant. Just a simple and poor families struggling for basic necessities. 8. Kochavva Paulo Ayyappa Coelho (2016)  A young boy of a middle-class boy has a dream of traveling by aircraft since a small age and always dreams of it. His family makes move to meet his father who is working in a Gulf county but the young boy is always prevented from achieving by his dream once by a disease and other time when his Father passes away. As he is devastated a man in the village encourages him to learn swimming by saying it will take him to a lot places in the world. The movie is circulated around the famous quote of Paulo Coelho “And, when you want something, all the universe conspires in helping you to achieve it.” In the end the boy achieves his dream of travelling by an aircraft. Truly this message is an inspiration to all the youngs lads. 9. Premam (2015)  As the name suggests as a romantic film, it got several love stories but what stays permanent is the friendship. The lesson that is gasped is the friendship is the best thing. Never sacrifice friendship for any love or relationship. In the end it will be us who regret for the sacrifice. 10. Marikutty (2018)  Hats off to Jayasurya who did this much dressing up to be like a transgender. The movie revolves around a transgender who is seen as a disgrace by the society and is been humiliated. This movie is to the public to understand the sufferings and pains of a transgender. They are humans too. Its not their fault to be born as a Trans gender. They have the same rights as we all have. They have the right to go to movie theaters, work in an office, play sports and everything. We all must see them as humans not as different species.  Movies aren’t always bad but it can also influence us in a good way and give us a good message. I recommend the youngsters to see the above mentioned messages. All of them are the new generation actors and they will love it.

If you really want to become a movie buff this is the one movie you should see or at least know the plot of .

There are no films one “must” watch. I would say though a serious film buff should take a tour of the great silent films, the Italian Neo Realist movement, the French New Wave, a dip into New German cinema, and frankly European arthouse cinema from the 50’s through the early 80’s in general. 70’s through 90’s independent cinema. The new Hollywood movement, Hollywood’s golden age, the great film noirs of the 40’s and 50’s, The European horrors and exploitation films of the 60’s and 70’s, the Hammer and Amicus library. Asian Action cinema of the 60’s through the 90’s. But basically whatever you enjoy, but try to pop out of the Hollywood mainstream once in a while and see what the foundation of modern film was build on. Because I guarantee the next film you watch will have moments and ideas that are build on past ideas, because filmmakers consume films.

Movies stimulate the imagination, but rarely thought. To they extent that they do stimulate thought at all, it is usually a well diluted tincture that merely hints at the richness of the underlying source material. If you want to think, read books. More to the point, read books from an era in which people were able to think complex thoughts, expressed in complete sentences, which made reference to well understood and shared memes that didn’t involve cats and pictograms. This is hard, especially for people who aren’t used to actually doing it. Here’s a few, which are informationally and philosophically dense, each sentence dripping with meaning and import: The Federalist Papers (Note! These were written for the common man, and published in newspapers! The indicate the extent to which the public discourse today is a degenerate, pale reflection of what once was. ) The anti-federalist papers. Democracy in America Or, if you want something more modern, read Eric Hoffer, The True Believer, Thoughts on the Nature of Mass Movements.

The father of all movies I have watched till date is V for Vendetta. A false imprisonment for half life just to prove a point and so much more. This is one Psychological/Philosophical movie that tops my list.  What if the law enforcement were smarter, better? It will cut down the crime, right? Well, watch Minority Report and gain a new perspective.  Who is greater? The creator or the creation? A whole new perspective comes to light after watching this. Ex-Machina  And, saving the best for last. If we really manage to change future, what guarantee we have that we will not ruffle the wrong feathers? The Butterfly Effect. The climax makes me sad, so sad. Hence, I do not want to change anything from past.

My Dinner With Andre.http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0082783/ It's best to say the film is indescribable, hard to convince yourself into enjoying, and yet gripping, in the quietest way imaginable. When I tell folks to find a copy and see it, which I do often, I say, "It's life-altering if you let it be." (In fact I'm sure I've said that on Quora already... somewhere... ) If you're looking for a movie to make you think—and leave it almost entirely up to you *what* to think, rather than pushing you into agreeing with the filmmaker's p.o.v.—this is one where you'll be thinking about it for a long, long time afterward.

This means, “What’s your favorite movie?” Who cares? I won’t answer that. It’s idiosyncratic. The “an . . . movie” implies you want one answer, not a bunch of diarrhea of opinions with exposition. Of all the movies I’ve seen, which isn’t all that many, and discarding my feelings or how the movie reinforces my present views, or even how it moves me . . . I think the one movie — as, and being a movie — you must watch is the best movie ever made, and the greatest story ever told. 2001: A Space Odyssey.

A great go-to classic for me is the 1932 film “I Am A Fugitive from A Chain Gang” — starring the terrific Paul Muni, who prior to becoming a movie star, acted on the stage in Yiddish theatre. The movie is based on a true story. In fact, the person who wrote the story was STILL a fugitive when the film was made, and was on the Warner Brothers set as a consultant… incognito, of course. What the movie is all about is all in the title. When it was released, it brought some (not enough) reforms to the prison system. GREAT ACTING and GREAT SCRIPT.

Though "Primer" was mentioned, Shane Carruth's sophomore offering requires even more attention from the viewer, as conclusions are not spoon-fed at all.  Lushly filmed, meandering and pensive, "Upstream Color" (Carruth's 2nd film) is definitely one to think about...I even had to look it up on Google to understand it (though when I did it made sense). Also, "Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy" (the Gary Oldman version) is one that requires quite some degree of attention, though it's eminently more approachable to a wider audience than "Upstream Color".  But neither film is one to watch on your way to bed - they both require active attention.

The dark knight the menace known as the Joker emerges from his mysterious past, he wreaks havoc and chaos on the people of Gotham, the Dark Knight must accept one of the greatest psychological and physical tests of his ability to fight injustice.

I’m a sucker for all romantic movies. But its hard to find a good romantic movie these days. I know about the Nicholas Sparks movies sure they are enjoyable and a tad cheesy but certainly not my taste. I tend to be a bit cynical. If you have watched The Notebook you might already know about the rain scene. My initial reaction to that was “C’mon that ain’t happening to me anytime soon or ever”. So yeah that's me. My recently I watched a movie called ATONEMENT. It changed my life. I repeat IT CHANGED MY LIFE. I mean nothing great happened but it made me feel certain emotions that I did not know I could feel. It crept into tiny corners of my heart and lit a candle in the most darkest of places. A practical judgemental person like me fell in love with it and to this day it remains my favourite romantic movie of all time. If you are looking for a movie to make your weekend that might be it. But I warn you it’s not for the faint hearted. If you are not into romantic movies that's completely fine with me. I don’t judge you. I watched a movie called DOUBT a while back. It features a stellar cast of Meryl Streep and Amy Adams. As the title suggests its about the human emotion of doubts in the mind. How that tiny doubt can build up and blow up way out of proportion and cause persons to accuse and lose trust. Hope this answer helped you. A fellow movie buff
